title: man who crushed partners toddler
story: NewsMan who crushed partners toddler to death vowed to "get rid" of witnessesStephen Waterson, , and Adrian Hoare, , deny manslaugher after little Alfie Lamb, three, had a heart attack after being squashed to deathShareByHayley Coyle:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsStephen Waterson said he could make people disappear "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man accused of crushing his girlfriends three-year-old son to death under a car seat threatened to “get rid” of anyone who revealed what happened, a court heard. Mum Adrian Hoare, , put little Alfie Lamb in the back footwell of an Audi A convertible before her boyfriend Stephen Waterson, , deliberately rammed the seat backwards against him, it was claimed. Alfie died three days after suffering a cardiac arrest outside the home he shared with the couple in Croydon, south London. Waterson and Hoare lied repeatedly after the event and assaulted the two other passengers in an attempt to cover up their crime, the Old Bailey heard. Today Hoares half-sister Ashleigh Jeffrey told jurors her sibling “had an amazing bond” with her toddler son.  The court heard Miss Jeffrey found out about Alfies death four days later, on February  last year and did “everything she could” to support her. Ms Jeffrey went with her to the hospital to see the youngsters body on February . During a conversation back at her flat in Kent she said she could see that Hoare “wanted to say something”. Miss Jefferson added: “She was holding back from whatever it was.” Jurors heard Hoare appeared “scared to say it”. When she later tried to ask her sister, Waterson and another passenger what happened in the car when Alfie was injured he would “jump in and take over the conversation”.  Jurors heard Waterson warned: “I’ll get rid of anyone who gets in my way or causes me trouble.” The court was told he also threatened: “I dont care what anyone in this room says, I know ways to make people disappear.” Ms Jeffrey said she met the following day with one of the police officers dealing with the case to discuss “trying to find out what happened to Alfie”. Ms Jeffrey said Hoare called her a day later, on February , and said she wanted to talk about the incident. Jurors heard Hoare knew Ms Jeffrey was going to record their conversation and an extract of it was played in court.  In it, Hoare can be heard describing how Alfie was behind Stephen in between my legs and the toddler was whingeing. It werent moaning like he was hurting or anything, she said. He had room there. Then Stephen moved his chair back and I was like move. I told him to move his chair forward and then because Alfie was still moaning he shouted at him. He went to move his chair forwards but Emilie was like leave him, hes got room, hes fine, so hes left his chair where it was. Hoare went on to explain how when they went to lt Alfie out of the car he was all floppy. Hes done that before, she added, describing how he would play-act when he didnt want to stand up.  But they quickly realised something was desperately wrong. Ms Jeffrey could be heard asking whether Alfie struggled or anything whilst he was in the car but Hoare confirmed he had not. The mother told her that Stephen started CPR, then couldnt do it and disappeared. When Ms Jeffrey asked her why everything had been kept a big secret, Hoare can be heard telling her: Everyone had to keep their mouth shut because of him [Waterson]. Everyone has to keep their mouths shut about whats happened. The two women went to Sutton Police Station later that day where Ms Jeffrey handed the recording over to the officer. Hoare and Waterson, from Croydon, south London, deny manslaughter. She also denies charges of child cruelty for placing Alfie in the footwell and common assault on Ms Williams on February . But Hoare and Waterson, have admitted perverting the course by submitting  statements to police. The trial continues.

title: pet dog plunges 100ft clifftop
story: NewsPet dog plunges from ft clftop - but miraculously walks away unharmedRNLI leboat team rescues plucky canine that accidentally fell into the sea at at Old Harry Rocks in DorsetShareCommentsByLouie Smith:,  JAN NewsDinky the dog with his owner and the RNLI crew "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dog which ran off the edge of a clf and plummeted ft into the sea has miraculously survived. Staffordshire bull terrier Dinky, who was not on his lead, had wandered off as his owner chatted to another walker. Then a splash was heard – and the distraught dog lover was sure his pet had tumbled to his death. But, luckily, the tide was in and an RNLI leboat was able to rescue the plucky canine uninjured. Coastguard Kerry Jury said: “The owner only shyrealised [what had happened] when he heard a splash in the water. “Dinky was in the water for a little while before a leboat, which was nearby on training duty, recovered him. “The owner was very relieved and the dog was freezing, so it was then taken to the vet’s.”   It is believed the surface of the water broke Dinky’s fall, allowing him to paddle to a nearby beach. He was then picked up by leboat crew and wrapped in a blanket before being reunited with his relieved owner. The man in his s, who did not wish to be named, took his pet for a check-up before going home to Yeovil in Somerset. The dramatic rescue happened at chalk clfs at the Old Harry Rocks beauty spot on the Isle of Purbeck, in Dorset, on Wednesday. Becky Mack, of Swanage Leboat Station, said: “He was incredibly lucky to survive the fall in the first place and avoid hitting any rocks on the way down. “But he was then at risk of the advancing tide. “Luckily we got to him in time. By the time we reached him, the dog was out of the water but still very cold. We put him in a blanket but he seemed visibly okay.” Mr Jury added: “We would advise walkers to keep their dogs on a lead.”

Conversely, the Queen was seen arriving at a WI event in West Newton today with no seatbeltA source told The Sun that Jaguar Land Rover was instructed to disabled the seatbelt alarm on vehicles supplied to the royals.The source said: “It’s so that the driver doesn’t have the continuous warning beepsthey don’t wear a seatbelt.” UK law stipulates that you must wear a seatbelt unless a doctor provides you with an exemption. British Safety Council chairman Lawrence Waterman told the paper: British Safety Council chairman Lawrence Waterman blasted: “It’s not asit’s onerous or dficult — and the law requires it.   Obviously these safety devices are a helpful reminder and I’m very disappointed as I do feel the royals should be setting a better example. Neither Jaguar Land Rover or Buckingham Palace has commented on the allegations. Former royal bodyguard Simon Morgan, of Trojan Consultancy, recently explained sometimes there might be a very good reason the royals are pictured without belts on. He claims that sometimes the royals dont buckle up as they might need to be ready to make a quick escape in an emergency. Speaking to Hello! magazine , he said: In the threat and risk matrix its a matter of looking at each inidual situation to decide what is the best way of achieving what needs to be achieved. For example, considering that a quick entry or exit to a vehicle is easier when people arent strapped into seatbelts.

story: NewsSheath Queen reveals what its like to clean horses GENITALS for a livingIMAGE WARNING: Mercedes Hoblin extracts beans - or smegma - from the tips of horses penises for £ per animalShareCommentsByChris kitchingPaige Ingram:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsMercedes Hoblin cleans smegma from the penises of horses"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman dubbed the Sheath Queen has revealed what its like to clean horses genitals for a living - and its a messy task that would make many stomachs churn. Mercedes Hoblin was in her third year in the care industry when she decided to make a dramatic career change in October last year. The -year-old mum, from Boreham, Essex, extracts beans - or build-ups of smegma - from the tips of horses penises for pound per animal. Its a dirty job, but someone has to do it - and Mercedes, who has has owned horses for years, told Essex Live she has never really minded cleaning their nether regions to keep them healthy.   Its a task that is often overlooked or not done regularly enough by owners of a gelding, a neutered male horse. Mercedes got her start by extracting beans - hardened masses of dirt and grime - from her own horses and others at her stables between  and . She then made it her business, charging pound per horse or pound per horse for a group of at least four. She said: It was quite a job change, none of my friends and family are horsey but I have owned horses for years and I never really minded cleaning that area of them. She added: My friend said it is a niche in the market and that I should do it full time so I started a Facebook page and now it is my full-time job. I did some research about vets finding these beans but it wasnt until I did it myself that I couldnt believe the size of them. They can be gigantic. She said: Most of my friends thought it was a bit of a joke at first, they are a bit grossed out by it all but they cannot believe how [my business] has taken off. I want people to be more aware of the problems these beans can cause because it can be dangerous for your horseleft untreated. She said a shop museum called Curiosities from the th Corner, in Battlesbridge, has approached her and expressed an interest in displaying some of the biggest beans she has collected. People dont want to pay for a vet to come out because they are so expensive so they often call me instead and eight out of ten times the horse will have a bean. When I first started I thoughtI can do about four a week it would be good but now I do around four or five a day. It usually takes about  to  minutes to clean a horses genitals. Mercedes said: First I use a gel and a spray to clean the area. It does depend on what type of dirt it is. Lara managed to contact the Australian consulate but said that their reaction was “lacklustre” and they merely advised her to find a safer place to stay.   She was too afraid to go to the local police also for fear of word getting back. Eventually Lara managed to contact the chief executive of an elite private members club for diplomats and the armed forces via Facebook . Dr Kaiser Rafiq told local police that Lara was being kept against her will and she was rescued. She stayed with him for a few weeks before flying to Islamabad to try to sort out how to get back home. Dr Rafiq told Daily Mail Australia: “I find her extremely genius and positive person but I was disappointed and somewhat angry at her for coming to a totally strange country and strange people whom she met only through internet. “Our youth must learn that the internet is not a safe place and we must not believe fantasies which someone portrays on internet.” Lara then contacted the British Pakistani Christian Association to try and get funds to fly back to Australia - who agreed to help her. Wilson Chowdry, head of the organisation, blasted the Australian government for not taking Lara’s plight seriously. She is now safely back in Australia and is campaigning so that other Australians in dficulty while abroad should not be “left behind”. To sign Ms Halls petition, clickhere.

title: budget tickets for tom jones dundee gig unavailable one minute after going on sale
story: The cheapest tickets for Sir Tom Jones# gig in Dundee#s Slessor Gardens could be sold out within minutes of being made available # with briefs already appearing on resale sites.The Welsh legend will belt out classics such as She’s A Lady, Delilah, and What’s New Pussycat when he takes to the stage on Saturday July .Within a minute of going on sale online today, Bronze standing tickets were showing as #unavailable# on ticketing site Ticketmaster.The briefs, which grant access to the Slessor Gardens space towards the rear, are on sale for £..However, they are already on resale site Viagogo for more than twice their face value, at £ each # excluding an eye-watering £ booking fee on each ticket and an unspecied #delivery fee#.This is despite a notice on Viagogo # hidden away in a #more information# link at the top of the page # which informs would-be buyers: #Resale of tickets is prohibited for this event.#Silver tickets which get fans closer to the stage are £. while Gold tickets, giving fans the best view and the closest access to the Welsh crooner, are £. a pop.The Tele was able to reserve Silver tickets on Ticketmaster # but when we tried to buy Gold or Bronze briefs, we were told by the website: #We couldn’t find the tickets you searched for.#Availability could y throughout the morning as orders are made and cancelled. title: dundee council in talks with promoter over exclusive rights to live gigs in slessor gardens
story: Dundee City Council is considering handing the exclusive rights to live gigs in Slessor Gardens to the Liz Hobbs Group, the Tele can reveal.The deal, likely to net the council a financial , would see the English event producer given the sole right to put on live music events in the open civic space.LHG has been responsible for every large music event in Slessor Gardens save for the D Festival that opened VA Dundee in .It has confirmed it has been in talks with the council.The authority has refused to acknowledge that discussions have taken place.However, other music promoters fear such a deal could lead to Dundee missing out on top artists who use other live event firms.Local promoter Events  says it has been “stonewalled” by the council in trying to arrange gigs.The Dundee company spent most of  attempting to arrange a Slessor Gardens gig for a multi-platinum band with the help of a large production company.It has declined to name either out of professional courtesy, but says the council has refused to provide it with tour dates on the grounds that an “exclusivity agreement” with LHG is in the works.Ronnie Smith, a director with Events , said: “This has been nearly  months we’ve been told the council is about to sign an exclusivity deal – and nothing .“The council has point-blank refused to discuss it.“Dundee would have wanted this band and we’ve ticked every box needed to make this work.“We fail to see why we can’t be offered the opportunity to put on a show for the people of Dundee.“The idea that irrespective of who we bring to the table it’s a ‘no’ before discussions start will put promoters off.”Events  is now considering legal action on the grounds that the deal is yet to be agreed.Other promoters, including DF Concerts boss Geoff Ellis, have spoken of their dficulty in arranging shows for Slessor Gardens.Mr Ellis said today: “Slessor Gardens is a fantastic space in the heart of Dundee city centre and we would love to bring some more acts to play there.”Since the venue began hosting gigs three years ago, the Liz Hobbs Group has brought acts such as Rita Ora, Little Mix, UB and Simple Minds, with Sir Tom Jones and Craig David on the way.Other artists on the company’s portfolio include Simply Red, Kaiser Chiefs and Paloma Faith.A spokeswoman for LHG said: “Discussions are ongoing regarding exclusivity.”Dundee City Council city development convener Lynne Short said: “There is no exclusivity agreement in place for Slessor Gardens with any promoters. The council is carefully considering the future of the space as a venue.”

title: dundee kids may be sent to school in angus in catchment overlap
story: The roll of an Angus school could be forced to expand after plans were unveiled to overlap its catchment area with Dundee.Councillors are being asked to consider the possibility of sending pupils who attend the Dundee City Council-run Barnhill Primary to Monieth High School instead of Grove Academy.Education chiefs believe accommodating a “signicant” number of the pupils who live closer to Monieth than Grove would alleviate placing requests at the Ferry school.Angus Council announced ambitions to build a new Monieth campus last year, but has not yet identied funding.Paul Clancy, the city council’s executive director of children and families services, will present his report to committee on Monday.He said: “Currently, Grove Academy experiences high levels of placing requests coming from west Ferry and Douglas whose pupils attending Craigiebarns and Claypotts Castle primary schools largely reside within the catchment area of Craigie High School.“One possible solution centres on the secondary educational provision of pupils residing in west Broughty Ferry attending Barnhill Primary School.“While the majority of pupils live within the catchment of and attend Grove Academy, a signicant percentage of its pupil catchment live closer to Monieth High School.”Monieth SNP councillor Beth Whiteside believes Angus Council will welcome the plan – on the grounds that a new “super-school” goes ahead at the Western Gateway.She said: “We currently transport approximately  pupils across the area every day, causing some of the problems with capacity.“The proposals make a lot of sense. We’re really supportive of both plans.”Education across the area is undergoing a major shake-up, with consideration also being given to a merger of Braeview Academy and Craigie High.

title: frozen meals can be just as healthy for dundee schoolkids as fresh food says expert
story: Serving frozen dinners will not affect the nutritional value of school meals, a leading food expert has said.Dr Karen Barton, programme leader for nutrition and health at Abertay University, said there would be no reduction in the nutrient content of frozen food compared to fresh, but said the most important thing for children’s diet is the content of the food.The Tele revealed this week that Dundee City Council, along with Perth and Kinross and Angus, is considering spending more than £ million transforming a food production centre into a “cook freeze” facility.Plans to serve Dundee, Angus and Perthshire pupils frozen school dinners instead of fresh meals" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp plans-to-serve-dundee-angus-and-perthshire-pupils-frozen-school-dinners-instead-of-fresh-meals embed # secretORxklxH" data-secret"ORxklxH" width"" "" title"#Plans to serve Dundee, Angus and Perthshire pupils frozen school dinners instead of fresh meals# # Evening " frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"The meals would be prepared at the Tayside Meal Centre and distributed to schools.The council has already anticipated a reduction in the number of meals because of the “misconception” frozen food is less nutritious than fresh.Dr Barton, who offers policy development advice on food issues in Scotland, said: “Freezing food is a method of preservation, it will not reduce the nutrient content of the food and in many cases it may actually mean that the food is more nutritious.“For example, frozen fruit and vegetables, which can be frozen quickly after harvest rather than stored or transported as fresh where some nutrients will diminish over time.”She added foods such as pies and those containing processed meats, frozen or not, are not regarded as healthy.“Certain types of frozen foods may not be regarded as ‘healthy’, but this is not due to the freezing process but the components of that food such as pies and processed meat.“Tayside Contracts will still have to meet the nutritional requirements for Food and Drink in SchoolsRegulations  regardless of the methods of food preparation andfoods are prepared in the a more standardised way nutritional content and food quality may be easier to regulate.“It is important that all those working in the food industry have a strong knowledge of preparation methods and nutritional standards and, as such, these are among the key areas studied by students on Abertay’s food and drink courses.”

title: historic dundee library set for 700000 upgrade
story: One of Dundee’s most historic libraries is set for a £, upgrade.Councillors are to be asked to approve plans for alterations and an extension at Coldside Library.Proposals include a new external lt and shaft, accessible toilets, upgraded lighting, new floor coverings and redecoration to the whole library inside and out.Lynne Short, convener of Dundee City Council’s city development committee, said: “Leisure and Culture Dundee raised proposals last summer to upgrade the library and I am pleased that the tender for the works has come forward and the council’s construction services ision is in line for the work.“This project will take one of our iconic th Century Carnegie libraries and give it a new lease of le fit for the st Century.”In , Dundee Town Council approached philanthropist Andrew Carnegie’s advisers about funding libraries throughout the city.After examining the proposals, Carnegie pledged £, to build five branch libraries in Dundee, including Coldside, which was designed by renowned city architect, James Thomson.Dundee was one of the first places in Scotland to provide its citizens with a free library, when in  the Dundee Free Public Library opened in the city’s Albert Memorial Institute, now The McManus.Members of the city development committee will consider the proposals on Monday.

title: jim mcintyre relieved as dundee remain in scottish cup
story: Dundee boss Jim McIntyre was relieved to still be in the Scottish Cup after his side scraped a draw with Queen of the South at Dens Park.Saturday’s fourth-round clash saw the Doonhamers deservedly move ahead through veteran striker Stephen Dobbie’s rd goal of the campaign.Although Jesse Curran struck a fine equaliser at the end of the first half, it was to prove the Dark Blues only shot on target over the  minutes.It was down to the heroics of debut keeper Seny Dieng, on loan from QPR for the rest of the season, that McIntyre’s men can look forward to a replay at Palmerston next week.And Jim conceded they were outplayed for much of the  minutes by the visitors.However, on a day of shock results that saw Motherwell and Ayr United go down to lower level opposition, Aberdeen held at home by Stenhousemuir and St Mirren having to battle back from two goals down against Alloa to edge through, being in the hat for the fth-round draw was a consolation.It will see Dundee face the Dons or Stenny away –they can come through the second game.“I thought Queen of the South were better than us. We didn’t start the game well,” said Jim.“These cup games are always dficult. Just look at the results around the other clubs and there’s been a few shocks.“I’m just glad that we’re still in the cup and we have another chance to recty that performance. We all know it was short of what we’re looking for.”If he was unhappy with his team’s work, the manager did stress the quality Queens showed did not surprise him.“You’ve got to credit Queen of the South. Give them a bit of credit, they played well.“You know what it’s like when a Championship or lower team comes to a Premiership club. You know they are going to be right up for the game and you know you are going to be in a fight.“They beat Ross County - last week which was a fabulous result against a team who’ve just knocked Motherwell out.”On top of getting another chance, Jim was pleased with the debuts he handed to Dieng, Craig Curran and second-half subs Andy Dales and Andrew Nelson.“The positives for me were the introduction of the newer players who all contributed and there will be better days ahead for us.”

title: mum of autistic boy spends 100 per week on school run after hire firm enters administration
story: The mother of an autistic boy left without school transport has been forced to spend £ in one week to get him to class.Kathleen Reid, whose four-year-old son Paul Ferrie attends Frances Wright Nursery, was told late on Friday night there would be no transport to take him to school.Private hire firm Airport Travel Dundee, who took Paul and other pupils to school on a council contract, plunged into administration suddenly last week.As a result, transport for Paul was abruptly stopped, causing the young boy a “huge” amount of distress. Kathleen is now having to get two private taxis a day to take her son to the nursery, as public buses are too distressing for him – setting her back £ a week.Kathleen, , said: “There is no transport for the kids at all, none for the foreseeable future. We have had nothing from the council. We have been put in a hellish situation.“It’s been awful for him. My son is severely autistic. A lot of the children are really attached to the drivers. They don’t understand how the bus disappeared and the driver is not there anymore.“Paul’s really upset. It has not been enough notice. It has been an absolute nightmare.“Some of these kids are in wheelchairs I don’t know how they are managing.”May Gow, whose son Lucas Kelly, , also attends the school, has also had to get a taxi.She says her son, who is being tested for being on the autistic spectrum, cannot cope with change and was also waiting for the bus that didn’t arrive.A spokesman for Dundee City Council said: “We are making every effort to find a replacement provider whose vehicles are suitably adapted for wheelchair users and other special needs. Parents will be kept informed of progress.”Airport Travel Dundee said: “We are no longer doing contracts with local councils.”

title: no excuses from nathan ralph for dundees poor cup display
story: If excuses were his thing, full-back Nathan Ralph wouldn’t be short of a few to explain Dundee’s below-par display as they were held at home by second-tier Queen of the South in the Scottish Cup on Saturday.After the three-week winter break, the Dark Blues were not alone in looking rusty as they faced up to the Doonhamers at Dens Park.Elsewhere, as other Premiership outfits got back to competitive action for the first time since the turn of the year, the fourth round saw Motherwell crash out at home to Ross County and Aberdeen held by minnows Stenhousemuir.Dundee were also facing a team that has been in fine form of late and who, in veteran Stephen Dobbie, can boast one of the best strikers in the country, not just the Championship.That they came to Dens and turned in a high level of performance should have come as no surprise.Last, and certainly not least, what turned out to be the first leg of this tricky tie saw Dundee hand debuts to no fewer than four players in the shape of goalkeeper Seny Dieng and attackers Craig Curran, Andy Dales and Andrew Nelson.With so many new faces involved, it was perhaps understandable the home team’s play at times lacked cohesion, though ironically at the weekend it was generally speaking the new players who were the pick of the bunch.That’s all the get-outs listed and Ralph isn’t too interested in any of them. For him, the bottom line is Dundee should have been better than this.“It was very frustrating on Saturday. I think our performance first half, we should be thankful we are still in the cup really,” he said.“It wasn’t good enough. They’ve got the goal to go ahead and then Jesse has done brilliantly just before half-time to get it back and have us level.“It was a good time for us to score and then we did definitely play better in the second half. On the whole, though, it was not good enough.“I suppose it does happen in the cup, we saw that with some of the other results, and the big thing is we are still in there and have a replay where we can make it into the next round.“So we maybe shouldn’t be too hard on ourselves over it but we’re still not happy with the performance.”Like most players after a bad game, now the -year-old just wants to get out on a pitch again and try to put things right.That’s why he breathed a sigh of relief on Sunday when Hearts’ televised clash with Livingston produced a result.Had the Jambos not edged past the Lions, a replay would have been tonight and Dundee’s Premiership visit to Tynecastle would have been postponed.“We have another game right away and that’s good. The one thing we didn’t want was no game this week because Hearts had drawn their cup-tie.“The thing you want to do after the winter break is get back into playing regularly again right away and you don’t want to be missing games because of things like that. You want to get points on the board as soon as possible.”Turning to the subject of the new arrivals, Ralph believes they will signicantly boost the chances of top-flight survival.So far, he’s been impressed by what he’s seen.He added: “I thought the new lads looked sharp and direct. They definitely want to get on the ball, create and make things happen.“I think them coming in this month will be good for the squad and they are going to help us going forward.”

title: tom duthie time has come for dundee united to finally show their true title credentials
story: From the low of a shock end-of-year defeat at Alloa leading to fears the goal for the rest of the regular season would be to secure a play-off spot, things are suddenly looking up for Dundee United.The arrival in person of new owner Mark Ogren came with a pledge to give manager Robbie Neilson the funds he needs to get promotion.And perhaps, just as importantly, the promise this is a long-term project andit doesn’t happen this term, money will be ploughed in to make sure it does next. It gave everyone with a liking for the Tangerines a lt.So, too, did a dramatic shrinking of the seven-point gap at the top of the Championship courtesy of Neilson’s team taking four points from consecutive home games, while top two Ross County and Ayr United each lost two in a row.That means, for a few hours at least, United can join leaders County on the -point markthey win the second tier’s game of the weekend at Ayr on Friday night.They would, of course, still trail the Staggies, who have a vastly superior goal dference, but just being up there would be another boost.A win would also cancel out the game in hand Ayr hold over United, though they too have a better goal dference. And whatever happens at Somerset Park, Ian McCall’s team will be above themthey beat Inverness next midweek.Perhaps, though, the biggest benefit to United this weekend can be the type of performance that, whatever the points, makes a statement that they’re the ones to beat. That, unfortunately, is something they’ve largely failed to do in three seasons down in the Championship.Past glories, some of them recent, mean United start every campaign as favourites for promotion.And any team walking into Tannadice on a Saturday sees a club geared for football in the Premiership.Too often, however, any edge that’s given United has disappeared because of performances.Even when they’ve lost, in the last two-and-a-half years sides have come out of games against them feeling reputation and expectation have not matched the sum of the parts of the team they’ve faced.Results like two defeats away to Dumbarton the season before last, a - loss at Falkirk last term and two five-goal home losses in this campaign, have led to opposition throughout the ision believing they always have a chance when facing United.In truth, even the draw with Partick Thistle this month and the win over Dunfermline that closed the gap at the top to those three points, were not as convincing as was expected.That’s repeatedly been the case during the two failed attempts to get up. In the big games, too often United have come up short.They did beat Hibs at Tannadice near the end of  but lost heavily to them soon after and quickly dropped off the pace at the top.Andthey won twice at Tannadice against last season’s table toppers St Mirren, the first time came before the Buddies were regarded as their main rivals and the second after Jack Ross’s team were out of sight at the top.This time round, the best so far came up in Dingwall in November when County were beaten -.Without taking anything away from that success, after Paul Watson’s early goal put them ahead, the three points were secured via a gritty rearguard action.Yes, it was the kind of performance that is needed at times in a successful league campaign.So, too, do emphatic victories that tell the rest of the league you are a team to be feared. There would be no better time for such a statement than Friday in Ayrshire.

title: Bid to create new whisky centre by Loch Ness
story: TALES of illicit whisky distilling on the shores of Loch Ness may feature soon in a new visitor centreplans for the facility get the go ahead from Highland Council.Hospitality and tourist operator Cobbs is teaming up with the Dingwall-based GlenWyvis Distillery to create what is being billed as the Loch Ness Whisky Experience.If approved by planners it will be sited in a redeveloped cottage by the lochside Clansman Hotel, which Cobbs owns.GlenWyvis Distillery opened in late  as the worldrsquos first  per cent community-owned, fully sustainable distillery producing single malt whisky and craft gin.It was denied permission to open its own on-site visitor centre last year amid concerns about accessibility, though it says it is still working with the council to resolve that situation.Highland Councils transport planning team are seeking more information on a number of matters related to the proposed Loch Ness development, including traffic impact and access to the A public road, but Cobbs managing director, Fraser Campbell, believes it is an exciting project with huge potential."Abriachan and the area around the Clansman Hotel was well known for illicit stills and I know the distillery has a lot of information and history which will feature at the visitor centre," he said."It is important we bring more tourists to the area and give them things to do when they are at Loch Ness."The Clansman runs fantastic boat trips, but not everyone wants to go on a boat so we want to bring other visitor experiences to the loch."We approached the distillery. They think itrsquos a great idea and we think its a great idea and of course it will be a great means of promoting their product."He added: "We get lots of bus tours from Invergordon to the hotel and this development will also help reduce traffic and help the environment because it means they will not have to spend half a day on the road travelling to a whisky experience where."GlenWyvis managing director John Mckenzie said: "This opportunity has come at the perfect time for GlenWyvis. It will give us access to a global audience and it will provide a great forum to engage with visitors who are interested in the story of whisky from a Highland community perspective. This is about the story of grass-roots distilling, distilling for the people, and, of course, that is what underpins the community ethos of GlenWyvis."The aim is to have the new visitor attraction up and running by this summer but to develop it further after that, providing both interactive and interpretative displays, as well as a retail facility.Friday  Jan  : AM

title: Broken lift leaves Inverness retirement flats residents stranded
story: RESIDENTS of a retirement complex in Inverness have been left disappointed, disgusted and even frightened by a range of issues which they say goes well beyond simple teething troubles.Problems affecting the Oakwood Court development in Crown ndash which is built on the grounds of the former Inverness Royal Academy building ndash include a lt which has repeatedly broken down, leaving some elderly residents effectively stranded on the upper floors, leaking pipes and badly sealed showers which have resulted in waste water and raw sewage seeping into some flats.The car park is also poorly lit and therefore a trip hazard.Residents of the -flat site are now contemplating legal action against operator McCarthy and Stone.Residents also have concerns about the electric supply and telephone system, with telephone lines not connected or fitted in wrong flats.Resident Paul Wells said problems with the lt were the biggest issue.ldquoWe have  apartments and only one lt, which is totally unreliable, he said.The lt broke down on seven occasions between late August and the end of the year, including four days over Christmas.ldquoSome people just didnrsquot go out of their apartments because of it, it was pretty dismal, Mr Wells said.Mr Wells said there were also safety issues in the car park.ldquoWe have some very uneven surfaces and so far we have had four residents trip over at night because lighting in one part is virtually non-existent, he said.ldquoAs you can imagine, wersquore pretty fed up. We donrsquot see it as being trouble-free living at the moment. We have paid over the odds for our apartments because we were after a certain lestyle and Irsquom sure we will get it, but in the meantime, it is very frustrating and frightening for some of our residents and, in terms of the car park, quite dangerous.The residents raised their concerns in a meeting with McCarthy and Stone management , but remained unsatisfied with the response. They are now speaking to a lawyer about the possibility of legal action, Mr Wells revealed.A spokeswoman for the firm said it was very sorry to hear about the problems, but it had been working hard to resolve defects.ldquoIn line with our commitments to all of our customers, we will ensure that any such faults are rectied as quickly as possible with the minimum of inconvenience, she added, and encouraged customers to raise any concerns with staff.Friday  Jan  : AM

title: Bucket loads of fun in store for Inverness
story: A CHILDRENrsquoS hospital charity is teaming up with one of Scotlandrsquos most iconic characters ndash and is on the hunt for someone to co-ordinate the Inverness end of the operation.This summer will see the Oor Wullie Big Bucket Trail rolled out across the country with more than  inidually decorated statues of the cheeky comic character set to grace city streets between June  and September .As well as drawing attention to the work of The Archie Foundation an auctioning off of the figures at the end of the event is also expected to raise thousands of pounds for its work in making hospital stays more pleasant for children.Around  of the statues are set to grace Inverness streets and an invitation has already been issued for creative types young or old to submit their ideas for how they should be designed.There is also a vacancy for a part-time artist co-ordinator to ensure the work is delivered by the June deadline.A spokesman for the foundation said the role would suit someone with an arts background who can co-ordinate submissions and manage artists.ldquoWe have just taken delivery of the fibre glass sculptures at a warehouse in Dundee and they will be distributed around the country in due course, he said.In terms of the designs to be applied to the statues he added: ldquoWhen we say we are looking for lsquoartistsrsquo to decorate these sculptures we are very flexible, because in Dundee we have already had one decorated by a group of children putting their handprints all over the sculpture. Sothere are community groups out there who would like to give their take on Oor Wullie we would be delighted to hear from them too.Design ideas can be submitted online until January  at www.oorwullie and applications for the co-ordinator post should be emailed to hello@archie.orgFriday  Jan  : AM

title: Chance to win a kilt and help Inverness charity
story: KILT wearers are being offered the chance to win themselves a custom-made kilt package worth pound to help an Inverness appeal.A made-to-measure kilt, tweed jacket and waistcoat are being raffled to raise money for the Haven Appeal to develop Scotlandrsquos first integrated centre for children and young people with multiple and complex needs.The raffle is being organised by Angus Beaton and Gary Smyth who teamed up to put the prize together.Both have family members with autism and also served together in the Queenrsquos Own Highlanders.Mr Beaton is a counter sales assistant at MacGregor Industrial Supplies in Henderson Road while Mr Smyth runs the family business, Scotkilt, in Harbour Road.ldquoI became aware of the Haven Appeal because my -year-old grandson, Kyle, was diagnosed with autism when he was very young, Mr Beaton said. ldquoHe would benefit from something like the Haven Centre.The pound million facility will have specialist indoor and outdoor play areas, respite flats, a community-run coffee shop and garden and offices.Mr Beaton and his colleagues at MacGregor Industrial Supplies raised pound for the appeal last year through raffles, bake sales and a tuck shop.Mr Smyth became involved in the appeal as he has a son with autism.ldquoAs like any family with this going on, it has its challenges and there needs to be more help in the Highlands for us all, he said.The jacket and waistcoat along with the kilt will be made for the winner at Scotkilt.The appeal, launched by the Elsie Normington Foundation and supported by the Inverness Courier, has raised pound. million towards the proposed Haven Centre to be built in Murray Road, Smithton.Tickets for the raffle, which will be drawn on March , cost pound each or people can donate via www.justgiving fundraising angus-beaton.Details of the project can be found on www.havenappeal.org.uk.Friday  Jan  : AM

title: Demands to tear down Inverness eyesore that has lain empty for 20 years
story: FRUSTRATION is growing among community leaders over a lack of progress to tackle a long-standing eyesore within sight of Inverness Castle.B-listed Viewhill House has stood empty for more than  years and was in poor repair when it was ravaged by fire in .Since then, the roofless shell has remained a carbuncle on the city skyline, shrouded in scaffolding, overgrown bushes and weeds.Pat Hayden, chairwoman of Crown and City Centre Community Council, believes it is time to consider knocking it downthere are no feasible restoration plans for the building ndash once the home of Victorian engineer Joseph Mitchell and later a youth hostel.And a leading city chartered surveyor agreed, saying it was beyond economic repair.Mrs Hayden said the eyesore would ruin the view from the castle once it is turned into a visitor attraction, adding: ldquoThey are going to stand on the hill and look around them, see Viewhill and wonder what on earth it is.ldquoPersonally, I think it should be demolished. You cannot preserve something which is no longer viable. We have waited far too long for something to happen.She is due to meet Highland Council officials later this month to discuss the future of the site.Chartered surveyor Richard Smith, managing director of Allied Souter and Jaffrey, said Viewhill should come down.ldquoIt is worth absolutely nothing unless you get permission to demolish it because the renovation far outweighs its value, said Mr Smith, whose company handled the sale on behalf of the Youth Hostel Association.He also queried its listing which he claimed followed a hurried request from a council official and without a visit from the listings authority.ldquoIt was a bad listing from the point of view that it was not checked out properly, said Mr Smith, who gave a ldquostab-in-the-dark valuation of pound, for the site, based on permission for demolition and redevelopment for a residential property.At one time Viewhill was owned by building firm Ewen Gillies and later acquired by Magnus Propertieswhich is believed to be the present owner. The companyrsquos director has a correspondence address in County Antrim.Highland Council is not in active discussions with the owner and David Haas, Inverness city centre manager, said it was up to the owner to push forward any plans.ldquoAs a council, we recognise the importance of that site and will work with stakeholders who have responsibility for it to develop any opportunities, but at the moment we are not in a position to do that, he said.ldquoObviously, we are very keen to see it brought back into use.Inverness Central councillor Bet McAllister agreed action was now needed.ldquoI have spoken to other people who are really fed-up about it, she said. ldquoPeople think it is a disgrace.Highland Historic Buildings Trust previously pressed the case for the restoration and conversion of the property into eight-serviced apartments, but has been unable to raise the costs, estimated at pound. million in .Chairman John Duncan stressed the trust was not the owner or potential developer but got involved to try and find a solution.He said any application for demolition would have to be determined by the council and Historic Environment Scotland.In connection with another controversial Inverness building, aquestionmark hangs over when the former Eastgate Hostel will be demolished, despite previous assurances that eyesore would start to come down next week.Talks took placeon Thursdaybetween Highland Council and representatives acting for the owners of the building which has remained a fire-ravaged eyesore for  days now.Afterwards, neither party would confirm whether work would begin next week, although they insisted the meeting was ldquovery positive.Chiropodist Jim Crawford, whose business is nearby, called for the council to take out a compulsory purchase orderwork does not start by next Friday.ldquoThere has been no sign of activity so far, he said.ldquoIt is an absolute nonsense.Building consultant Gary Johnston, agent for the owners Imtaiz Ali and Mr Cheng, would not confirm when work would begin. All he could say was: ldquoEverything is going according to plan.David Haas, Highland Councilrsquos Inverness city manager, said matters were progressing in a constructive way.ldquoIt is very frustrating it has taken so many years to get to this stage but the principal owner has taken major steps in the last six months, he insisted.Friday  Jan  : AM

title: Drive on to extend free parking in Inverness city centre
story: CITY businesses are pushing for an extension to free parking in the centre of Inverness as a year-long trial they have hailed as a success comes to an end.Backed by the Inverness Courier, Inverness Business Improvement Districtpersuaded Highland Council to introduce a system of free  minutes of on-street parking last year across a broad swathe of the city centre.Parking meters were converted to provide free tickets for  on-street spaces, after research suggested similar schemes have had a positive impact on footfall in other urban centres such as Perth.The trial period is now coming to an end and business figures, who argue it has been a hit, are hoping it will be extended ndash both in terms of the amount of time shoppers will be able to enjoy free parking for and the number of sites they can us.Local butcher Duncan Fraser who has premises in Queensgate said: ldquoThe businesses I have spoken to would like to see it extended to half an hour.ldquoFteen minutes is fine, but a bit tightyou have to go to a couple of shops or get caught up in the post office.ldquoWe certainly would not like to see this withdrawn.And David Miele, who runs the hugely successful Mielersquos Gelateria in Church Street, is also hoping councillors will look at making better use of the parking space available.ldquoThere are too many loading bays which lie empty for most of the day, he said.ldquoWhen wardens pass our premises customers basically get up and go out because they fear getting a ticket.ldquoI welcome the free parking and would like to see it increased.They are being backed in their calls by Inverness Central councillor and depute provost Bet McAllisterldquoIt has clearly been welcomed by the traders and enables people to get in to the town centre and attend to business, but you canrsquot do a lot in  minutes, she said.ldquoI would rather see it extended to half an hour so people can pop into a couple of shops, go to the library or even stop for a coffee.And she added: ldquoMany older people would benefit greatly from a longer stay.ldquoWe have to look at the bigger picture. The Victorian Market is generally used by older people and it needs more customers. Longer-stay free parking would help.BID manager Mike Smith said it believes the free parking has been beneficial.ldquoInverness BID subscribes to the view that parking is all part of the city centre marketing offer to the public, he said.ldquoWe appreciate the financial pressures Highland Council is under, but we should not lose sight of that mantra.Shane Manning, principal officer for traffic and planning at Highland Council, confirmed councillors are set to evaluate the schemersquos impact when the Inverness city area committee meets on February . They will decide at that point whether to continue with it.Friday  Jan  : AM

title: Funding could lead to new life for Inverness park
story: A BOLD vision to transform a historic Inverness park into a vibrant green space and breathe new le into its dilapidated buildings could take a step forward later this month.Campaigners are exploring the possibility of transferring ownership of the Northern Meeting Park in Ardross Street to a community-run group in a bid to enable greater access to the venue.The Northern Meeting Park Group is now waiting to hear whether a funding application has been successful for a feasibility study to prepare a five-year business plan plus architectural reports and surveys.If all goes according to plan, the study could begin before the end of January while the long-awaited project could be achieved by the end of next year.The group is also looking for two trustees from the local community ndash taking in the neighbourhoods of Park, Balleary and Dalneigh and Columba ndash to join its -strong board.Chairman Jon Ford expects this year to be a busy one in trying to push forward the proposals for the -year-old park whose gates are usually kept locked.The group has applied for a grant from the Scottish Land Fund with advice from Highlands and Islands Enterprise and hopes to get match funding from the Architectural Heritage Fund.In total, the initial studies are expected to cost pound,.ldquoWe know there are a lot of other people out there also looking for funding but we are very optimistic, he said.ldquoThat would be the first stage. The next stage would be to apply for funding to acquire the Northern Meeting Park and have it transferred into community ownership.Highland Council would also have to agree to transfer ownership of the park.Mr Ford acknowledged there had been some resistance from a few councillors including those who had mistakenly thought the idea was to turn the park into a private business venture.ldquoNone of us likes change, he said. ldquoI can understand it on one level but not on another when you are talking about a publicly-owned asset which is kept locked up and not used especially as it is four acres of grass in the city centre which could be used for recreation.ldquoI cannot understand why people are resistant to that notion. In our view this is a way for Highland Council to think outside the box.Hundreds of people accessed the park during a two-week trial last summer when the gates were opened each day between am and pm.Mr Ford hopes a similar trial will be carried out around Easter.Anyone interested in becoming a trustee can contact the group via www.northernmeetingpark, or call  .Friday  Jan  : AM

title: Go ahead for River Ness hydro scheme
story: A SPECTACULAR hydro electric scheme close to the heart of Inverness has been given the green light by Highland Council, and it is hoped it will not only be a source of power, but also an attractive feature on the River Ness.Council officials granted the application for the lsquoArchimedes screwrsquo to be built into the bank next to Holm Mills Bridge near the West Link distributor road but have placed a total of  conditions on the project to safeguard visual amenity, road and pedestrian safety.The project has been warmly welcomed with local councillor Alex Graham, he said: ldquoThis project was first mooted about three years ago and then it came back towards the end of last year. Historically hydro power was generated there in the s in the building that is now the ice-cream shop.ldquoIn the present climate I think it is a very welcome project, one that can not only generate power locally but also become a feature to be enjoyed by visitors and locals.Helen Smith, who is on Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoWe didnrsquot comment on it but it is tucked away quite far from residential buildings. But from my point of view, personally its fine, I remember there was hydro power there in the past and it might be quite attractive. Irsquod be surpriseit bothers any local residents.Friday  Jan  : AM

title: Highland arts venue has strategy to combat fund gap
story: THE regionrsquos biggest arts venue has outlined how it must become more financially resilient.In its latest accounts, Eden Court in Inverness reported increased income and more expenditure in the year ending March ,  compared to the previous  months.Last year Eden Court lost pound, a year of funding ndashpound, from Creative Scotland and pound, from the Highland Council.A trusteesrsquo report the figures stated: ldquoThe principal risks identied are financial ones, particularly the effect of this yearrsquos signicant reduction in public funding.ldquoThe organisation must become more financially resilient by growing sources of earned income and building a safe level of reserves.ldquoAs public funding declines, the targets for earnings from trading activities necessarily increase, and the risk that these targets cannot be met also increases. At the same time, our cost base is likely to increase owing to inflationary pressures on resources.ldquoThis year we are working on a strategy for trading through our funding gap, increasing income from charitable trading, reducing costs wherever possible and developing partnerships to share services.ldquoAttention has also been focused on non-financial risks arising from the loss of some channels of regular communication with our major funders our relationship with both Creative Scotland and the Highland Council has been strengthened during the year to March ,  and subsequently.ldquoThe development of positive relationships with funders ndash public organisations and inidual philanthropists ndash remains a high priority and is a central part of Eden Courtrsquos financial strategy for the coming three years.Total income increased from pound,, in  to pound,, last year. For the same period, total expenditure moved from pound,, to pound,,.Total funds also went up from pound,, to pound,,.Advance ticket sales mean that Eden Courtrsquos cash flow position remains strong.The biggest event of the year was the Snow White panto, which sold more than , tickets for its  performances.The report stated: ldquoAttendance for the year has been unprecedented with audiences of , for live performances and , at film screenings. The financial contribution from live performances was pound, higher than budget, boosted by some musical performances in the summer months and an excellent result from our Christmas pantomime.The wholly owned subsidiary Eden Court Trading experienced a rise in turnover from pound,, in  to pound,, last year, and an increase in pre-tax profit from pound, to pound,.The report added: ldquoOver the past four years we have seen substantial growth in trading through our restaurant, cafeacute and bars, and also in sales of confectionary, show merchandise and programmes by our front of house team.ldquoOur trading activities in   resulted in a surplus of pound,, an increase of  per cent over the previous yearrsquos result.ldquoWe will also implement a new strategy to attract philanthropy from trusts and foundations, and from within our community.Friday  Jan  : AM

title: Hope that Inverness special needs project can be saved
story: Highland Councilrsquos refusal to fund the Special Needs Action Projectin Inverness has triggered outrage across party lines with councillors and members of parliament queuing up to slam the local authority.Conservative councillor Andrew Jarvie, said: ldquoNot only is this a devastating blow for dozens upon dozens of vulnerable children and young people, it symbolises everything that is wrong with this council administration.Mr Jarvie complained the decision to refuse funding was taken in private, saying: ldquoThis secrecy and behind closed door decisions wreaked havoc on rural communities last year but I find it absolutely disgusting to inflict the same on the most vulnerable people in Highland.ldquoFor SNAP to run such a comprehensive and valuable year round service for pound, a year tells me that they are already managing their funds stringently and that any cut is a gross insult to both the organisation and its users.MP Drew Hendry met with SNAP management last week and he said: ldquoAnybody who knows about the great work SNAP do would also be very concerned by the uncertainty around their future and just how dficult it would be to replace the work that they do.ldquoA better way forward must be to secure their immediate future and to work with them to find sustainable funding for coming years.ldquoThis approach has worked successfully before and I have pledged to do what I can to support SNAP and the council to find a better outcome.Friday  Jan  : AM

title: Inverness charity issues go orange plea for fundraising effort
story: INVERNESS charity Leorsquos Pride is encouraging people to lsquoGo orange for a dayrsquo as ambassadors in this yearrsquos Muscular Dystrophy UKevent on February .The national campaign has been running for three years and has so far made more than pound, by encouraging schools, workplaces and iniduals to wear orange for a day and make a donation to MDUK.Additionally those taking part can choose to wear sunglasses or even set up a mock-tail bar, in order to raise funds.Leorsquos Pride is a local organisation which was set up for Leo Flett, who is three-years-old and suffers from Muscular Dystrophy . Leorsquos mum Louise said: ldquoThe support we have had since starting almost a year ago is absolutely incredible and we continue to be touched by peoplersquos kindness and generosity.Mrs Flett said: ldquoWe are totally blown away by this yearrsquos response. We have been very lucky and honoured to have been asked to be ambassadors for the day this year by MDUK which means a lot to us considering wersquore still so new.The charity is raising money to continue their work finding new treatments and campaigning for better care and support for people with muscle-wasting conditions to ensure them the best possible quality of le.Muscular Dystrophy UK regional development manager, Dean Widd said: ldquoA huge thank you to everyone in Inverness looking to take part in the national Go Orange for a Day on February . We are delighted that over a dozen schools, clubs, academies and businesses have registered to take part in support of our Scottish family fund Leorsquos Pride.Mr Widd said: ldquoIt is thanks to the incredible efforts like this that we are able to continue to fund pioneering research into potential treatments for muscular dystrophy as well as supporting families. With more than , people in the UK living with muscular dystrophy and other muscle-wasting conditions, it is important to do whatever we can to make a dference.Leorsquos Pride is also organising an event in April called Pride  after last yearrsquos event which made over pound,.Friday  Jan  : AM

title: Inverness schoolgirl coining it in thanks to generous donation
story: AN Inverness schoolgirlrsquos coin collecting hobby has received a boost after she was given a bag of assorted coins by a well-wisher.The man, who insisted on remaining anonymous, came to the Inverness Courier office with the money after we ran a story about Isla MacDonald becoming online coin club Change Checkerrsquos award-winning junior member of .Islarsquos interest in specially minted coins was sparked by the finding of a Girl Guides centenary p and now the Cradlehall Primary pupil has  special p coins and  dferently designed pound coins.Her father Simon helped her to research the first coin and she began keeping an eye out for other coins which are unusual and collectable.Her mother Luisa said: ldquoIt is a shame this man has asked to remain anonymous because we would love to write a thank you letter to him. It was really kind of him. Isla is delighted and fascinated by the selection of coins that was in the bag.Islarsquos coin collection includes several rare items, including coins marking the Commonwealth Games in England, London Underground and Paddington Bear.Like her fellow collectors, she is keeping a sharp eye out for Kew Gardens which remains the most scarce p coin currently in circulation.Among the gted coins is a  pound coin issued to mark  years since the Declaration of Rights being enacted which effectively shted the balance of power from the Crown to parliament and changed the course of British political history.Another is a pound coin which was minted in  to mark the centenary of Entente Cordiale, agreements made between the UK and French governments.Two Cornish halfpennies, and a pound and p from the Isle of Man are also included, as well as a square coin marking the bicentenary of the Battle of Jersey.Although not a coin, the bag included a highly nostalgic ldquoOfficial Licensed Medallion marking that Scotland had qualied for the  World Cup in France. Five World Cups have come and gone since without Scotland managing to qualy.Friday  Jan  : AM

story: Dundee United could be set to make a move for ex-Aberdeen attacker Peter Pawlett.Pawlett, , left Pittodrie for MK Dons # where has featured just seven times this term # in .Reports claimed Tannadice boss Robbie Neilson, who signed Pawlett for MK Dons, now wants him to help with United#s push for the Championship run-in.The Banchory-raised player was key member of the Dons# League Cup-winning side in , although he missed the final with injury, and made more than  appearances for the Reds.

title: childrens charity in plea for more volunteers
story: A Childline volunteer in the north-east has called for more people to join the charity.Linda Stephen was recently awarded a British Empire Medal for her nine years voluntary work with the organisation.The -year-old has called on more people to get involved with the Aberdeen base to help children who might be dealing with a range of problems including bullying, self-harm and suicide.She said: “Receiving the award was very unexpected and is quite humbling. I am very grateful to be nominated but I don’t feel I deserve it because there are many committed volunteers who do lots of great work.“The important thing for me is that young people know about the Childline service sothis award raises Childline’s profile then that’s brilliant.“I see the award as being more of a recognition for the whole Aberdeen Childline base, volunteers and staff.“Volunteering for Childline is very rewarding in a few ways. You are there for children and young people who need someone to listen to them.“It is sad there is so much anxiety and depression among young people – that seems to be very common just now – so it’s vital that Childline is there for young people.”

title: msp urges north east woman to go for smear test
story: North-east MSP Gillian Martin is encouraging women to go for their smear test.It comes as the charity Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust aims to raise awareness during Cervical Cancer Prevention Week.In the UK, cervical cancer is most common in women aged between  and , and more than , people are diagnosed with the disease every year.The quick screening check cells on the cervix for any changes that can then be monitored or treated.Figures have revealed that last year cervical screening uptake in Scotland fell from .% to .%, meaning that more than one in four eligible women missed their test.Ms Martin, SNP MSP for Aberdeenshire East, said: “I am delighted to be working with Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust this Cervical Cancer Prevention Week.“Cervical screening prevents up to % of cervical cancers developing.”Smear tests are routinely offered every three years to women aged between  and , and every five years for those aged between  and .Women should contact their GP surgery to make an appointment.

title: marian travels back to the hollow mountain
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsMy book about the project, Cruachan: The Hollow Mountain, was published to coincide with the th anniversary of its opening. Invited to join Cameron up at the Cruachan dam for the second of his two recent programmes, I was delighted to tramp the mighty mountain with Scotland’s Number one authority on outdoor pursuits.As an author and broadcaster, Cameron always has an eye on a good story, and so as well as asking me about the lack of health and safety regulations at the time the hydro project was being built, he also wanted to knowthere really was a murder during the construction. There was, as I told him, a body – but the body wasn’t identied, no arrests were made, no court case took place.It would be a shamethat construction period went down in history as an invasion of , workmen – #Tunnel Tigers# as they were dubbed – into one of Argyll#s most beautul settings and a possible murder.My book was intended to give the story of the local people whose lives were punctuated by this ambitious construction project. Quite rightly, those Tunnel Tigers had been lauded in a number of publications. The work that was done hollowing out Argyll’s highest mountain to provide electricity for the nation was amazing.The plan for Cruachan – as for the other major hydro projects of the post World War II era – was conceived by Tom Johnston, to whom I dedicated my book. Johnston was a politician who remained true to his ideals of bringing rural Scotland into the modern world. There was no power in the Highlands, and without power there could be no industry and no prosperity. The engineering genius was Sir Edward MacColl, whose biographer Norrie Fraser called him #a maker of modern Scotland#.Cruachan was the first reversible pumped-storage system in the world. During its years of construction from  to , eminent international engineers visited the project to see how the water was pumped between two reservoirs through reversible turbine generators. At off-peak hours, the water was – is # pumped back up to the reservoir you see high up in the corrie above Loch Awe, held back by a dam that is now so much a part of our landscape. The loch itself is the lower reservoir.I had imagined that the scale of such a project – using Scotland’s top engineering companies who shipped in workers from other parts of the UK and Europe – would have been a cause for resentment and protest by local people.That, of course, failed to take account of the vision of the folk of Dalmally, Lochawe, and Taynuilt. Although it took men with engineering experience to blast the  miles of tunnels, hollow out the mountain itself, and construct the dam, there was also a need for a support army. There were clerks and porters, joiners and caterers, folk willing to let out a room, a caravan, a house, serve in a pub where just occasionally it was necessary to keep a baseball bat behind the bar to maintain bonhomie. The project kick started careers, fortunes and marriages, and gave the area good roads and a tourist industry.If you haven’t visited the hollow mountain or walked Cruachan’s slopes, make  the year you do.[In bold please] Cruachan: The Hollow Mountain is available from the Argyll Book Centre in Lochgilphead and all good book shops, along with Marian Pallister#s other books of local interest.PICS:The Pass of Brander before work started. no_aCruachanLe before the project # the Loch Awe Hotel with steamers. no_aCruachanThe Queen opening the project in October . no_aCruachanWorking on the  miles of tunnels. no_aCruachanWorking on the road to the dam, overlooking Loch Awe. no_aCruachan

title: coleman and aliyev impress ardrishaig
story: Robert LaceyUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs the lights dimmed in Ardrishaig Hall on Saturday January , and the audience chatter subsided, two young men, dressed entirely in black, strode into view.Jâms Coleman sat at the splendid Yamaha grand piano that for all visiting musicians must be such a relief to see, while Jamal Aliyev carefully set the spike of his special Giovanni Gabrielli Cello , an instrument re-discovered after a -year absence from public performance.Then the music began and the dark first notes of Beethoven’s Cello and Piano Sonata op. no. in G minor filled the hall. It was written for Count Friedrich Wilhelm, supposedly simplied for amateurs to play. However, Jamal and Jâms being master musicians showed the power of this often disregarded piece, to be immense. One of the first works to make piano and cello equal musical partners, it is full of ingenious dialogue between the instruments. The structure is unusual, but with such expert performers it delighted the audience who were moved by every turn and twist of this deeply emotional work.Jâms, from North Wales, after remarking on the three ferry crossings required to get to Ardrishaig via Bute, introduced the next piece, Ernest Bloch’s work ‘From Jewish Le’. In a style close to Jamal’s heart and heritage, having been born in Baku Azerbaijan, its three elements, ‘Prayer’, ‘Supplication’ and ‘Jewish Song’, are full of the pathos and sorrow felt by the Jewish nation and also full of the signature augmented intervals and minor key tonality of much of middle eastern musics. How beautully these pieces demonstrated the lyrical qualities of the cello. Jamal’s bow searched for all possible nuances of tone and dynamic as his instrument sang from its lowest notes to a seductive soprano register.The concert continued after the interval with a second Beethoven work. The audience may have noticed a minor kerfuffle at the piano as many pages were rapidly turned before starting. Would it be the ‘Seven Variations’ for cello and piano or the ‘Twelve’, both based on themes from Mozart’s Magic Flute  The ‘Seven Variations’ won, being on the theme from the ‘Pamina’ and ‘Papageno’ duet entitled ‘In men, who know the feeling of love’. This work exhibits Beethoven’s practised ingenuity in the iation form and brought a lighter mood to the programme.Jâms Coleman introduced the final work, Frank Bridge’s Cello Sonata. He told of the four years of torment for the composer as he struggled to express his feelings about the First World War, finally finishing the composition in . The adagio in the piece caused the composer the most dficulty as he struggled with ambivalence about his own pacist views. Jâms and Jamal dealt with the challenges of this complex work which tracks huge changes in the world of music composition that were under way at that time. Again, the lyrical powers of the cello came to the fore as did the virtuosic requirements heaped on the pianist. Despite its undoubted innovations, this piece generously reaches out to its audience. Bridge uses the new musical freedoms only when justied, being happy toto more traditional tonal stability in the lyrical sections.Fulfilled, but not overburdened by the weightiness of the final piece, the audience applauded Jamal and Jâms back to the concert room to perform the ‘Swan’ from Saint-Saens ‘Carnival of the Animals’ as encore. This piece so beautully confirmed the excellence of Jamal’s playing and the superb quality of his quite special instrument.PIC:Jamal Aliyev and Jâms Coleman. no_aJamalandJam

title: over to you inveraray as projects make progress
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowChairman Derrick Anstee opened the latest meeting of Inveraray#s community company bemoaning the loss of local amenities since he first visited the area  years ago.From banks to police station and pier to tourist office, all these things have gone.It was the job of Inspire Inveraray, said Mr Anstee, to #do something about the decline in this town#.Around  people attended the Nicoll Hall to hear an update on projects being pursued by Inspire Inveraray # involving the community hall, Inveraray Pier and even the acquisition of a phonebox.The Architectural Heritage Fund, assisted by a grant from the An Suidhe wind farm community fund  has allowed a structural engineer#s report to be completed on the community hall. In summary, Mr Anstee explained, not a lot had changed since an earlier report, though a lot of remedial work would be needed.Mr Anstee added that the question is: #What use to people want to make of the hall  Do we need it at all #The next question is whether the hall should be demolished and a new facility built or whether the facade should be retained # for which heritage grant funding may be available. A sense of frustration was evident in the hall as people heard about surveys and consultation # a familiar theme for Inspire Inveraray since its formation three years ago.Hotelier Donald Clark clearly wants to see action and is not keen on retaining the old building. He said: #It#s an eyesore. I think we need to work on the premise of demolition then decide on the use of it.#Next it was on to the vexed question of Inveraray Pier. Numerous attempts to start a dialogue with the owner Archie MacArthur had failed, said Mr Anstee.One approach Inspire Inveraray is looking at is to attempt to purchase the pier using community Right to Buy legislation. There is also the question of whether to bid for the puffer, which Mr MacArthur is trying to sell, as well as the pier itself.To get to the bottom of the community#s views, consultant Charlotte Lee has been employed to pull together opinions and draw up a community action plan.Of only slightly lesser importance is the telephone box in Church Square, in which Inspire Inveraray has expressed an interest. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby
