title: Caithness Moray link is completed
story: THE Caithness-Moray electricity transmission link will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come, the man who led the project has said.Dave Gardner, director of transmission for Scottish and Southern Electricity NetworksTransmission, was speaking after it was announced that the construction, commissioning and energisation of the link had been completed at a cost of around pound million.He hailed it as a signicant achievement for SSEN and everyone involved."Caithness-Moray has been a highly complex project, requiring very high standards of project design, development, construction and commissioning," Mr Gardner said. "It has been delivered by a team of committed and skilled people, working closely with contractors and other stakeholders."It will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come."Now an operational asset, we will closely monitor the link and associated infrastructure to ensure its continued success as an integral part of the GB transmission system."We would like to thank all those who contributed to the success of the project, from our own teams of engineers and support staff, our supply chain and the local communities who have played host to our project teams over recent years."Caithness-Moray is the largest single investment ever undertaken by the SSE Group and is described as the most signicant investment in the north of Scotland electricity transmission system since the s.The link uses HVDCtechnology to transmit power through a km subsea cable beneath the Moray Firth seabed between new converter stations at Spittaland Blackhillock . Constructed over a period of four years, the project also involved work at eight electricity substation sites.Completed on time and within the allowance approved by the regulator Ofgem, the Caithness-Moray link provides up to MW of capacity to transmit power from the increasing sources of renewable energy from across the far north.The link has already enabled turbines from Beatrice offshore wind farmand Dorenell onshore wind farmto connect to the national grid with a further MW of onshore generation in Caithness and Ross-shire due to connect in the coming months.The completion of the link and other electricity transmission projects is expected to help take the Regulatory Asset Valueof SSEN Transmission to around pound. billion at March , .Friday  Jan  : AM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Friday  Jan  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Friday  Jan  : AM

title: Sir Chris top peak is Suilven
story: HE has conquered Everest and is considered Britains greatest living mountaineer.But climbing luminary Sir Chris Bonington has told top travel guide Wanderlust that Suilven in north-west Sutherland is the mountain that most shaped his le.Sir Chriss career has included  expeditions to the Himalayas, including four to the worlds highest mountain, and the first ascent of the south face of Annapurna.The mountain was immortalised last year in the film Edie, in which Sheila Hancock stars as an octogenarian who makes a le-changing decision to climb its steep, remote slopes.Sir Chrissaid: "Suilven is a long whale-back of a mountain, but when you approach it from the west you just see the end of it ndash an absolutely perfect peak, with a great sandstone buttress."I first climbed Suilven when I was  and it is one of the most magical days I have ever had."It was my second holiday in Scotland, just after I had discovered climbing, and I went up with a friend. We carried our rucksacks, hitch-hiked, and bivvied most of the time. I remember sleeping in the ruins of Ardvreck Castle ndash it was the only thing with a roof on it for miles ndash before we set off from Lochinver to climb Suilven."We tried following a route which wasnt very good, so we ended up climbing a new route."The views from the top of Suilven were incredible. To the south there was a big, wide loch, dotted with islands."That day captured everything that I love about climbing and inspired me to keep doing it ndash the sense of exploration, the beauty of the mountains themselves, as well as the experience of really stretching yourself in the process."Second on his list was the North Face of the Eiger, ahead of the Central Tower of Paine, Chile.The Old Man of Hoy, Orkneys ft sea-stack, was placed fourth on his list. Sir Chris made the first ascent of the Old Man of Hoy in  and climbed it again in ."I was the first person to climb the Old Man of Hoy and the oldest when I climbed it again when I was ," Sir Chris said.Friday  Jan  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Friday  Jan  : AM

title: Upgrade should just be the start
story: THE pound. million upgrade of the north section of the Berriedale Braes should be the trigger to improve the rest of that part of the A, according to Caithness councillor Raymond Bremner.He made the plea after Transport Scotland confirmed the contract to upgrade the notorious north hairpin bend has been awarded to Dingwall-based engineering company R J McLeod Ltd. Work is due to start this year, be completed by spring  and create  jobs during the construction phase.Councillor Bremner, who represents Wick and East Caithness on Highland Council, said: "While Im keen to see an improvement to the north brae, I still believe we cant take our focus off the south brae. We have two major long-term concerns to focus on here ndash the gradient of the brae and the fact that we are still witnessing serious accidents on the bottom hairpin bend even where there is an escape bed."These accidents are a risk to le, causing road closures and impacting in all sorts of ways on our local community and economy. Improvements to the north brae are very welcome and I hope that it is the start of a bigger vision to improve the entire Berriedale Braes."We can expect the standard lead-in period of about three months and for discussions to be held with the contractor on how they propose to physically approach the works and discussions with statutory bodies like the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds among others."He said that archaeological investigatory works have been completed.The award of the contract was also welcomed by Trudy Morris, chief executive of Caithness Chamber of Commerce.She said: "We are delighted to see that after many years of dedicated campaigning by the chamber, Caithness Transport Forum and other local organisations, this project is finally moving ahead. For too long, the Berriedale Braes has acted as a pinch point for travellers on the A north of Inverness, disrupting business and jeopardising investment in the region."It has been good to see other work on A improvements and repairs going to local companies in recent years, and we hope the principal contractor will engage closely with our highly skilled local supply chain as these works progress."Ms Morris added: "Now that the contract has been formally awarded, we hope to see clarication on exact start dates and expectedof works very soon. We would urge the Scottish Government to uphold its previous promise to start works within this financial year so that the north Highlands can start to see the benefit of this upgrade as soon as possible."A Transport Scotland spokesman said: "R J McLeod Ltd has been awarded the construction contract as part of the pound. million project to deliver improvements to the road alignment and the existing tight hairpin bend on the A."Michael Matheson, cabinet secretary for transport, hailed it as a positive development for the area. "It will enhance the skills development of the Scottish construction industry, with approximately  jobs expected to be supported in the region during construction."Related articles:Four in running for Berriedale Braes contractSilence on A schemeFriday  Jan  : AM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Friday  Jan  : AM

title: invitation to tender issued for northern isles ferry contract
story: An Invitation to Tender for the next contract to run the Northern Isles ferry services has been issued to three bidders, the Scottish Government announced today, Thursday.Submission of final tenders is scheduled for March, with a view to awarding the contract in July.The contract is estimated to be worth £m and will run for eight years. The names of the companies involved have however, not been released.Minister for energy, connectivity and the islands, Paul Wheelhouse, said: “Issuing the Invitation to Tender marks the next stage of the process to award the new contract to operate the Northern Isles Ferry Services.“The contract will run for eight years, allowing us to build a strong working relationship with the successful bidder, and all the routes within the network are being tendered as a single bundle.“The Scottish Government remains fully committed to high quality ferry services to the Northern Isles. A key benefit of this new contract is the in-built flexibility, allowing the ferry services to be amended to reflect future changes in demand across the important sectors of the islands’ economies – tourism, fishing, food and drink, aquaculture and farming. Scottish Ministers will also retain control of all of important issues, such as fares and timetables, through the public service contract.“We are committed to a fair, open and transparent tender which aims to get the best possible deal for the communities that depend on these ferry services.”• Commenting on the issue, Northern Isles MSP’s Liam McArthur and Tavish Scott said: “The Scottish Government have finally issued the tender. The timescale is very tight indeed given the operator needs to be up and running the North Isles leline ferry services in  months’ time. It is essential that companies make constructive bids with improvements to the existing service. It must, in particular, recognise the growing freight volumes that are being exported south to the Scottish mainland.“So the tender bids must be properly assessed to ensure the service moves forward and not backwards. And the endless saga of RET must come to an end, otherwise how can bidding companies submit a proposed fare policy ”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: oic makes urgent call for ferry funding
story: Orkney Islands Council is again calling on the Scottish Government to honour a commitment to provide fully fair funding for the county’s inter-island ferry service — or it will hand the service back to the government to run.The council is warning it cannot afford to run the service during the year ahead unless the government covers the full cost involved — this amounts to £. million. OIC Leader James Stockan has notied Ministers that the council will hand over responsibility for running the service to Transport Scotland, unless sufficient funding is provided.A year ago, a similar level of support was secured, after a y campaign by OIC for fair funding. Of this, £. million was allocated to fully fund Orkney’s internal ferry service during the current financial year, with £ million awarded to Shetland Islands Council for its ferry operations.“But this time there is no specic amount allocated to Orkney or Shetland. The government recognises that it will cost £. million to operate our ageing fleet of ferries during - — and that is what we are asking the government to provide.”OIC is also looking to the government to fund the replacement of the current inter-island fleet. The council has been working with the government on this for a number of years and is currently developing a business case setting out the service levels local communities require, and the engineering options needed to achieve these.Councillor Stockan added: “We would object in the strongest possible termswe end up with a reduction in our ferries funding. This would place a wholly disproportionate and unfair burden on the smallest council in Scotland and would mean us having to make cuts to other vital services.“The ferries are a leline for remote and fragile communities across our islands. Orkney has the oldest fleet and the highest fares in the country — an inequality we cannot address without proper financial support from the Scottish Government.We are calling on the government to take an honourable approach to fulfilling the will of the Scottish Parliament that we should receive fair and equitable funding for our inter-island ferry service. The principle of transferring Orkney’s internal ferry service to the Scottish Government, at no net detriment to OIC, has already been approved by the council. That is a route we will have to take unless we are provided with the funds to run the service over the year ahead.”For the full story, pick up a copy of The Orcadian, this Thursday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: the essence of orkney photography competition dont forget to cast your vote
story: The Orcadian is calling on all budding young photographers to submit their photos for our Essence of Orkney photography competition.As part of the competition, we will be awarding one lucky entrant under the age of  with a camera bag and photography voucher, a £ voucher for The Orcadian Bookshop and a large framed print of their winning pictureRunners up will also win their picture printed on a canvas. Entrants under the age of  must obtain the consent of a parent orprior to submitting any images.We have a special online viewing gallery for the competition, which allows people to submit images, check out the competition, cast their vote and share the top images to gather support.The competition has asked photographers of all skill levels to submit images that capture the very Essence of Orkney in the winter, bringing a fresh perspective to island le. We want to see entries that move away from the iconic imagery of Orkney, offering a new narrative.We are delighted to have teamed up with The Pickaquoy Centre for a special exhibition of the absolute best of the bunch.Fteen shortlisted entries from across the three categories will be on show at the centre in February, and the public will be able to vote by ballot on the top five in the People’s Choice Category.Submissions will be accepted until Thursday, January . The exhibition will run from February  to March .Winners of the competition will be announced at the launch of the  Orkney Islander magazine at the end of March, following on from the exhibition at the Pickaquoy Centre.Visit www.essenceoforkney to submit your entry, and don’t forget to share the link on social media to boost support for your work!copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: A temporary one-way system is in place ready for street improvement works to begin in Kirkwall.The works are part of Kirkwall Townscape Initiative’sPlace and Spaces project and will begin at the top of Castle Street and the bottom of the Strynd.The initial phase involves the paving outside the front of the TSB, with work then planned for the paved area in front of Foubister and Bain. title: Business masterclass aims to put Highland entrepreneurs ahead
story: ENTREPRENEURS will learn how to create and sustain a competitive advantage at an event in Inverness next month.Professor Eleanor Shaw, executive director of the Hunter Centre for Entrepreneurship and vice dean of Strathclyde Business School, will deliver a masterclass on February  and  at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness.The event, which includes a networking dinner, is organised by Highlands and Islands Enterpriseas part of its entrepreneurship programme.Prof Shaw said: ldquoBy creating a competitive advantage, businesses can set a buffer between them and their competitors in turn creating a more secure place in the market.ldquoThe way in which we approach executive education at the University of Strathclyde is dferent ndash we put the focus on the participant in the room, looking at their needs and providing access to toolkits and learning so after the masterclass they can start working with colleagues and honing their value proposition straight away.ldquoEverything we do has been road tested by working with entrepreneurs and wersquove learned that creating a competitive advantage can help a business in many ways.ldquoIrsquom really looking forward to working with Highlands and Islands entrepreneurs, sharing our learnings and making new connections in the region.Louise MacDonald, senior entrepreneurship manager at HIE, said: ldquoCreating and sustaining a competitive advantage can be dficult in todayrsquos ever-changing and dynamic environment.ldquoBusinesses need to think strategically and be able to analyse their proposition to find ways to enhance impact, value and performance.ldquoThe masterclass will teach entrepreneurs from across the region the tools and techniques to stay ahead of the game.For more information, email entrepreneurship@hient or visit www.hie masterclassesFriday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. For more details of these cookies and how to disable them, see our cookie policy.

title: Conon Bridge school travel plan set for an upgrade
story: PARENTS of children in a village that has witnessed a surge in housebuilding are being asked to have their say on a new school travel plan.The appeal centres on Ben Wyvis Primary in Conon Bridge. A survey has been issued seeking information on issues such as what factors influence parentsrsquo decisions on whether to let their children walk or cycle to school and how much they value safer crossings, vehicle speed-reduction measures and improved road safety education as well as information on the benefits of walking and cycling.The survey includes questions about the distance pupils attending Ben Wyvis Primary live from the school and the modes of transport they use to get there.It also seeks views on measures that could reduce congestion at the school gate. These include involvement in voluntary cycle training and a car sharing scheme.Itrsquos part of a wider effort across the Highlands to work on safer routes to school, reduce unnecessary car use and encourage healthier alternatives where possible, such as walking and cycling.The survey, supported by the parent council, can be found online and completed at www.surveymonkey r BenWyvisPSFriday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. For more details of these cookies and how to disable them, see our cookie policy.

title: Easter Ross filmmaker turned author gets to art of matter in new novel

title: Fresh deal is a sign of our intent says firm at Invergordon port

title: Highland arts venue has strategy to combat fund gap
story: THE regionrsquos biggest arts venue has outlined how it must become more financially resilient.In its latest accounts, Eden Court in Inverness reported increased income and more expenditure in the year ending March ,  compared to the previous  months.Last year Eden Court lost pound, a year of funding ndashpound, from Creative Scotland and pound, from the Highland Council.A trusteesrsquo report the figures stated: ldquoThe principal risks identied are financial ones, particularly the effect of this yearrsquos signicant reduction in public funding.ldquoThe organisation must become more financially resilient by growing sources of earned income and building a safe level of reserves.ldquoAs public funding declines, the targets for earnings from trading activities necessarily increase, and the risk that these targets cannot be met also increases. title: Life saving Ross shire Womens Aid centre issues action plan after mixed report
story: The Dingwall-based Ross-shire Womenrsquos Aid centre has received a mixed inspection report from the Care Commission watchdog.While the quality of care and support provided to abused women and their children was judged good, the quality of management and leadership was rated ldquoadequate.One woman told inspectors that the service was a le-saver and she wished it would receive more funding.However there were times when staff felt inadequately supported by management, said the report following the unannounced inspection. The report stated: ldquoSince our last inspection there had been changes within the management team and this had impacted on the overall quality of service provision.ldquoThe service provider acknowledged this was an area that they were under-performing in and as a result, an interim management team had recently been put in place. We met with the interim management team and noted that good progress was being made to address many areas we identied as needing improvement. We were also provided with a detailed action plan which identied immediate and future areas for improvement.ldquoAs a result of our findings we concluded that the service was currently operating to an adequate standard. Should we have found that the recent management team were not making signicant in-roads to address our concerns we would have graded the management and leadership as weak.ldquoWhen we spoke with staff, all said that they had been faced with many challenges and that there were times when they felt totally unsupported by management.It said staff continued to work in a dedicated and caring way, were well trained and experienced.It added: ldquoHowever, we were also aware that staff had been faced with a challenging time due to changes in the management of the service. This had clearly impacted on staff morale and a feeling of being unsupported at times. We have highlighted this as an area that needs to be improved on in the management and leadership theme in this report.Eight women who responded to the inspection questionnaires were happy overall with the quality of care and support provided.During the inspection comments noted included: ldquoThe service from Womenrsquos Aid is a le-saver ldquoMy care worker has supported me through the worst and shown me how far I have come, and ldquoI just wish they could get more funding so they can continue to provide this le-saving service.Friday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Lochcarron cafe aims to cash in on success of NC500
story: A WESTER Ross communityrsquos bid to take advantage of its presence on a world-renowned visitor route and provide fresh opportunities for local people has received a pound, boost.Lochcarron Community Development Company is behind plans to redevelop an underused building at their existing community hub.It has won a pound, award from the The Princersquos Countryside Fund to support the redevelopment at the Smithy Community Hub, which provides workspaces for local craftsmen, a tourism information point and a community treehouse.The group now plan to turn a building on the site into a community cafeacute and shop, selling produce from local crofters and craft workers.The eco-friendly project will include a recycling point and facilities to charge electric cars, regarded as vital given the hubrsquos location on the busy North Coast  route.The building work is expected to take four months, and the fund has committed to support the salary of a project officer for a further year-and-a-half.Kristine MacKenzie, development officer at Lochcarron Community Development Company, said: ldquoOur vision for the Smithy Community Hub is to deliver economic, social and environmental benefits to a level capable of making a dference for local people and provide an enhanced experience for visitors.ldquoInformed by local circumstance and need, the underutilised community building will be refurbished and extended to accommodate a deli selling local produce, a craft outlet, a cafeacute and community learning space.ldquoOverall, the project will help tackle inequality, increase social interaction and reduce isolation, help address the current skills and employment gap, the high level of outward migration of young and replace some of the services recently lost. Recharging the community spirit will lead to a more sustainable future.She said funding from the Princersquos Countryside Fund would assist with training, the purchase of equipment needed to establish the produce outlet and help pay for a project officer.The result of additional funding bids will be known in the coming weeks.Claire Saunders, director of The Princersquos Countryside Fund, said: ldquoRural communities across the UK suffer from a loss of amenities such as shops and places to socialise, and this is felt even more keenly in remote areas such as the Scottish Highlands. title: Support blooms for Invergordon garden project
story: A BID to save an under-threat gardening project for learning disabled adults in Easter Ross has won public support amid growing efforts to secure its long-term future.NHS Highland has withdrawn its funding for the initiative at the Isobel Rhind Centre in Invergordon, saying it cannot afford it.But at least , people have signed a petition backing the initiative and more than pound of a pound, target to fund a six-month extension has been raised thanks to the support of well-wishers responding to a crowdfunding drive set up by Cromarty Firth councillor Maxine Smith.A local businessman has also promised to match fund whatever is raised through the drive.Cllr Smith said thateveryone who signed the petition chipped in just pound, it would ensure a breathing space for the  users who have helped brighten up Invergordon with hanging baskets.Efforts to find a new model to deliver the scheme have been going on behind the scenes and NHS Highland has said that although funding will stop, the land at the centre can continue to be used. However, health chiefs have been accused of dragging their feet over helping to find a sustainable future model to deliver the scheme, which many of the users have said gives them a reason to get up in the morning.The project leader, who is employed by High Le Highland, has been told funding will end this month. According to Cllr Smith, garden users are ldquodevastated but adamant they wish to continue.She wants to see NHS Highland play a full role plotting the way forward, including carrying out self-directed supportassessments, a tool that aims to ensure people who are eligible for support are given the choice and control over how their inidual budget is arranged and delivered to meet their agreed health and social care outcomes.Tain-based Mike Herd, whose son has happily attended the scheme in Invergordon, said: ldquoNHS Highland made a commitment to me last year that they would try to help the garden project continue through a dferent funding formula. However, the reality is that letters asking for SDS funding have been ignored. It seems that NHS Highland have just abandoned the gardeners to a bleak futurelong-term funding cannot be agreed.Cllr Smith added: ldquoI make a plea, especially to big businesses locally, to contact me and offer some funding towards this worthwhile project that gives the adult users with learning disabilities pride and a reason to get up in the morning.ldquoIt is only a one-off payment I am seeking, not continual funding.NHS Highlandrsquos head of service for learning disabilities and autism, Arlene Johnstone, said: ldquoDue to financial pressures NHS Highland is no longer able to contribute funding to the Garden Project in Invergordon. However, we are supporting Councillor Maxine Smith in her efforts to find a new funding model and we have offered that,successful, they can continue to use the land in the grounds of the Isobel Rhind Centre. We have also introduced her to colleagues who have been able to advise of potential ways forward.ldquoNHS Highland is committed to ensuring that people with a learning disability can participate fully in our communities and therefore are also in discussion with High Le Highland and Councillor Maxine Smith to explore alternative ways of providing the activity that people enjoy. title: calls for haggis emoji to be introduced ahead of burns night
story: An award-winning#haggis#maker is calling for Scotlands national dish to be represented in the language of emojis.McCaskie Butchers in Renfrewshire said that haggis should be included in the list of emojis available, following in the footsteps of other national food favourites such as pizza, sushi, pretzels, burritos and croissants.Nigel Ovens, owner of McCaskie Butchers, which has created a design of what the emoji could look like, said: "In the run up to Burn’s Night, and indeed at other times of year, I want to be able to share my enthusiasm via text message and on social media and so I hunted for a haggis emoji – without success. "I really believe a haggis emoji would be well used as a great way to celebrate Scotland’s famous dish but also as a great way to celebrate Scotland as a whole."He said that Scots celebrating Burnss Night would benefit from the emoji, sharing their love for the haggis with friends across the world.He said: “We wanted to launch this campaign so that haggis lovers could demonstrate their passion for the dish, share recipes and help this wonderful product to be recognised by this ubiquitous and modern international language. Tourists visiting Scotland may also have some fun by using the haggis emoji as part of their messages to friends and family at home. If haggis is given the distinction of being granted its own emoji then the wider message is strong that the product is moving with the times, appealing to the masses and continuing to make our nation proud of its food heritage all year round as well as on Burn’s Night."Graeme Sharp, spokesman for Quality Meat Scotland, said: “Scotland is internationally renowned for its iconic national dish so what better way to spread the word and inspire people to buy haggis this Burn’s Night than a haggis emoji "Originally developed in Japan, emojis have been in international use since , hitting the mainstream in  when the Oxford English Dictionary named an emoji one of its ‘words’ of the year.Haggis-lovers can support the campaign by using the hashtag #haggisemoji or by signing the petition.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: brexit the people must have final say leader comment
story: The UK is heading towards the economic disaster of a no-deal Brexit # unless MPs back either Theresa May#s deal or a second referendum. If they won#t support May, they must give the final say to #the people#.It is indeed a “disgrace”, as Airbus chief executive Tom Enders lamented, that more than two-and-a-half years after the Brexit referendum, we still do not know what is going to happen on  March.But everyone should be very clear that, at the moment, the UK is heading for a no-deal Brexit unless our MPs take action to prevent it.Just last week, one of two courses of action that would prevent a no-deal – Theresa May’s Brexit plan – suffered the biggest government defeat in the Commons for more than a century. And yesterday, MPs who support the other option – a second EU referendum – admitted the idea did not have enough support and withdrew an amendment to next week’s vote on May’s deal.: Mike Russell: Scots ‘have right’ to consider independence as Brexit alternativeConservative MP Sarah Wollaston said they had done so with “great regret” but that, without the support of Jeremy Corbyn, the amendment would have failed. Labour MP Luciana Berger called on her party leader to “do the right thing”, adding that Labour should not be “facilitating a job-destroying Brexit”. Corbyn’s inability to get off the fence, coupled with May’s stubborn determination to stick with her deal, is pushing Britain ever closer to the now infamous “clf-edge” of a no-deal, as hardline Brexiteers celebrate. In their latest dubious pronouncement, Lord Tebbit claimed that this outcome would result in cheaper alcohol.As The Scotsman has repeatedly said,MPs want Brexit to happen on  March, they should vote for May’s plan. It will damage our economy – as will all forms of Brexit – but it will be as nothing compared to the impact of a chaotic plunge into World Trade Organisation rules. Our economy is far too closely intertwined with the EU’s for such a sudden wrench and we are woefully unprepared.: Lord Tebbit: No-deal Brexit will mean cheaper booze for UKAs Enders warned,the UK does not alter course, Airbus could move its operations out of the country. Many more firms may do the same. Sony has announced its European base is to move to the Netherlands and that country’s government is in talks with more than  British companies about relocating.MPs have an over-riding duty to act in the national interest – evenit may be unpopular. Right now, it is clearly in the national interest to delay Brexit to allow the will of the people to be expressed once more. We the people now know what we are getting intothe UK leaves the EU. It’s only right that we are given the final say.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: why ban on nicola sturgeon meeting theresa may has lifted paris gourtsoyannis
story: #Nothing has changed# has been the cynical, ironic refrain for the months,not years of our Brexit purgatory. Well, something is changing. You can tell from the fact Nicola Sturgeon was in Downing Street on Wednesday night.Remember that not long ago, the UK Government was happy to let it be known the First Minister of Scotland was barred from meeting the Prime Minister. Months could pass without high level meetings between the Scottish and UK Governments.Until the end of last year, Downing Street wasn’t keen on having Sturgeon around because with Brexit in chaos, all it did was give the SNP leader a chance to trash Theresa May in front of the cameras outside Number ’s door, unanswered.This week, the UK Government issued the First Minister a special invitation. Devolved administrations were offered an “enhanced role” in Brexit talks and a seat on a key Cabinet sub-committee that will lead preparations for EU exit.: Nicola Sturgeon: Theresa May ‘running scared’ of independenceThe photo op now benefits both sides. Why  Because Downing Street and the SNP know they’re fighting a dferent battle. The war for Brexit is nearly over. They know the fight over indyref is upon us. Sturgeon was already struggling to resist vocal demands to produce a roadmap to a second independence referendum from her own supporters and parliamentarians. The outcome of Brexit will force her hand, in any case.Influential Scots in the UK Government know it needs better ammunition to fight the inevitable demand for another vote. David Mundell has written to the Prime Minister saying as much, and on Wednesday, both sides tested their new lines. Senior UK Government sources say they are ready. “Bring it on,” one told me – the fight about the referendum, not vote itself. Expect the Downing Street line against indyref to harden further.The path to a second independence referendum is at least as long and winding as the one the UK has followed towards Brexit day. Indyref might never happen. But whether the campaign ever begins in earnest, the phoney war started this week.: Theresa May says independence referendum the ‘last thing we want’©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: alex salmond remains defiant as he faces his darkest day
story: Alex Salmond cut a shaken, but defiant figure as he facedthe darkest day of his long political career.Some of the old pomp was clearly still there as the former First Minister shook hands with supporters on the way into Edinburgh Sherf Court yesterday, running a gauntlet of public and media onlookers with lawyer Callum Anderson and media adviser Campbell Gunn. Shouts of “freedom” rang out from supporters, along with more unsavoury barbs from those less well disposed to the former SNP leader.The hearing front of Sherf Frank Crowe in Court  of the Chambers Street building was held in private in line with the usual first appearance scenarios in “solemn” cases which cover more serious crimes in Scotland.It lasted just five minutes and hardly seemed worth the journey for the dozens of journalists who ventured into the court lobby.They were left trying to catch a glimpse through the doors of the action inside the courtroom while police officers stood guard to keep them out.And then Mr Salmond emerged to face the media. It must have felt like a letime – in fact just over a fortnight – for Mr Salmond since he stood just round the block outside the Court of Session to hail a dramatic victory against the government he once led over procedures it used toinvestigate complaints against him.Shouts of “Captain, My Captain” rang out from supporters as Salmond delivered a steadfast rejection of the charges and pledged to fight them. There were even flashes of thistrademark bullishness as he told reporters he would love to take their questions and talk some more, but court rules prevented him from doing so.It may be that the next chance he gets to speak publicly will be from the dock.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: alex salmond unique case is not unprecedented says advocate
story: Many people are asking whether Alex Salmond, with his major public profile, could possibly get a fair trial in Scotlandany charges proceed.Many people are asking whether Alex Salmond, with his major public profile, could possibly get a fair trial in Scotlandany charges proceed.If challenged, the court’s answer will be considered in the context of the publicity around the allegations. To date no case in Scotland has been stopped because of prejudicial publicity and that’s despite there having been some high-profile cases that attracted considerable, sometimes extremely prejudicial, media attention.These cases were dferent in that the accused were not well-known public figures, but it was argued that publicity about the allegations could prejudice any trial.I wouldn’t call this case unprecedented, but it has its own unique aspects. However, the challenges for the court have been considered before. Two examples are the trial of William Beggs for what became known as the “Limbs in the Loch” murder, and that of Nat Fraser, who was accused of killing his we, Arlene. There had been a great deal of reporting about the cases and the courts had to decide whether fair trials could be achieved. In both situations, the courts decided the cases could proceed fairly, referring to the safeguards of the passage of time between any publicity and a trial the focusing effect for a jury of listening to the evidence and the strong directions given to a jury in such cases to decide only based on evidence they hear in court.Those representing Salmond may argue that he is uniquely well-known and that some allegations against him have, to an extent, been canvassed in the media. They may say that it will be almost impossible to find jurors who have never heard of him. But that doesn’t matter – more to the point is whether it will be possible to find jurors that are untainted by prejudicial knowledge about the allegations.The Crown will say Contempt of Court rules apply and no-one can now publish anything that might prejudice the trial. There is now signicant protection in place and the media can only really report on procedural aspects such as the fact he has been charged.Very senior people at the Crown Office will be involved in decisions about possible proceedings once they have seen all statements and reports. Meantime, everyone on social and all other media must observe our strict rules about reporting live cases.John Scott is a QC Solicitor Advocate and president of the Society of Solicitor Advocates©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: snp heavyweights there is no appetite for a second independence referendum
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...Alex Salmond heaped further pressure on Nicola Sturgeon to demand a second independence referendum yesterday as senior figures within the SNP warned her against seeking another vote.The former first minister called on his successor to seize on the turmoilover Brexit engulfing Westminster by pushing for a second poll, while other leading figures within the party urged caution.Mr Salmond also pledged to end the “uncivil war” with Ms Sturgeon’s camp that has developed amid the fallout from sexual misconduct allegations against him. A police investigation is taking place into the allegations made by two women and dating back to when he was first minister. But Mr Salmond won a legal challenge against the Scottish Government over its handling of the claims.The Scottish Government is carrying out a review of what happened and Ms Sturgeon has referred herself to independent advisers to consider whether she breached the ministerial code during meetings and phone calls with her predecessor. Mr Salmond said Ms Sturgeon’s focus should be on the drive to bring about independence. He said: “Nicola should be concentrating all her energies on the independence agenda where we will never have better circumstances. As far as I am concerned Westminster’s Brexit dficulty should be Scotland’s opportunity.” Ms Sturgeon is to give an update to the Scottish Parliament on her plans in the coming weeks. A formal request for a Section  order which would give Holyrood the authority to stage a referendum was rejected by the UK government last year, with Prime Minister Theresa may insisting “now is not the time” to revisit the Scottish constitutional issue amid the Brexit uncertainty. It is understood that a further request by the Scottish Government would also be rejected by Westminster.Writing in the Sunday National newspaper yesterday, Mr Salmond said: “One of our features in the national movement has been our inability to weigh the strengths and weaknesses of our political opponents. We have tended to concentrate on the shape we’re in.“However, right now the Westminster political establishment is at its weakest point in my letime while the national movement is in good heart. There is not likely to be a better time to force the issue.”However former SNP deputy leader Jim Sillars warned there is “no appetite” for a second independence referendum. He said: “There is no national Yes organisation in place – a prerequisite to success as many Yes activists and voters are not SNP.“No policy work has been done on the post-Brexit situation and thus we are not in a position to deploy then new policies in that post-Brexit new paradigm that will be needed to convince No voters to vote Yes next time.”Polls indicate there has been no rise in support for independence among Scots since the last vote in  and Perth and North Perthshire MP Pete Wishart said a vote should be held when it can be won.He said: “We are already making progress towards that with Brexit as the catalyst. But it will be dficult to secure the conditions to make a referendum happen before the next Holyrood election.”Alex Bell, a former SNP government adviser also called for a more considered approach.He said: “The SNP and Yes have to stop seeing independence as a sneaky prize to be won when everyone  is messing up and instead base their campaign on the reality of what Scotland can achieve through an honest understanding of the world.”Ms Sturgeon had pledged to hold a second referendum in the immediate aftermath of Brexit but “reset” her plans after the SNP suffered heavy losses in the  UK election.At First Minister’s Questions last week, she said: “Given the catastrophe that Scotland faces in our economy, our society, our living standards, the prospects for the next generation and our reputation in the world, it is essential that the option of independence is open to people in Scotland.“When people in Scotland have the ability to choose independence, I believe that the country will opt to be an independent one.”The Scottish Parliament has already voted in favour of a second referendum following the Brexit vote as the SNP combined with the pro-independence Greens. Scottish Secretary David Mundell has written to Mrs May to urge her to maintain her refusal to grant Holyrood powers for a second independence referendum.If the authority to hold a second referendum through a Section  is rejected, as expected, by the UK government, it has been suggested that the Scottish Government could make this the central issue of the next Holyrood election in , as it seeks to build the case for a independence in the years ahead. Tory constitution spokesman Adam Tomkins suggested Ms Sturgeon will seek a Section  order in the knowledge it will be rejected by in order to “stir up as much grievance and bad feeling as possible”.Scottish Liberal Democrat Leader Willie Rennie urged the SNP to abandon plans for another referendum. A Scottish Labour source added: “The last thing Scotland needs is more instability and chaos of yet another independence referendum, what our communities need are Labour governments here and in Westminster to end austerity.”An SNP spokesman said: “With the clock ticking down to Brexit date - and with the Tory government incapable of governing and Labour incapable of effectively opposing - the SNP will continue to focus on standing up for Scotland’s interests in the face of a disastrous Tory-driven Brexit and further austerity.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: airport staff defended after criticism over parking system
story: A Bressay resident has praised staff at Sumburgh Airport after criticism over the newly introduced parking charges and the situation for disabled drivers.Last week Joyce Davies, from Skeld, bemoaned the new set-up. She said drivers with disabilities had to go to fetch their blue badges in order to prove they were exempt from the daily £ charge.Mrs Davies said some blue badge holders were simply opting to pay the parking fee, rather than #enduring the discomfort of doubling back on themselves to go back into the airport#., Kirsten Sim said her personal experiences dfered greatly from what was being claimed.Ms Sim said: #My son has mobility problems and uses his blue badge for identication purposes when flying to the mainland. On arriving at the airport, I wrote the name, serial number of the badge and expiry date on a piece of paper and left it on my dashboard, with a note saying that the badge is used for identication when flying and also while we are away.#On checking in, I explained this to the check-in staff, who said that that would be fine, but just to mention it to security on our way through. I did so and was again met with a very friendly and helpful response.#On ing to Sumburgh, Ms Sim said the system, which she had reservations about before, again seemed to be extremely easy and straightforward.She added: I am afraid that I disagree with your article, especially the part which says that #fellow blue badge holders # are simply opting to pay the daily charge ###On this occasion, my family and I cannot praise airport staff enough for their helpfulness and understanding.# raquo well done Kirsten#.!..

title: minister hears plea for debts to be written off
story: Locum costs, hospital bed closures because of staffing shortages and staff retention were among the issues discussed at NHS Shetland#s annual review meeting.The Scottish government#s mental health minister Clare Haughey was attending the meeting, which was held on Monday afternoon.It came after NHS Shetland was forced to close six beds at the Gilbert Bain Hospital because of a recruitment shortfall.Director of nursing Kathleen Carolan said she hoped to have the shortage addressed within three months.Ms Haughey#s visit came after the crippling costs of travel and accommodation connected to locum medical cover was highlighted late last year.During the meeting she was challenged by Shetland integration joint board vice-chairman Allison Duncan.He warned that Shetland had spent £ million on locum cover over  months.#We already know that other local authorities like Dundee and other NHS debts are going to be written off. Will you write off any outstanding debts that we have here in Shetland # Mr Duncan said.The minister said she appreciated locum costs were #perhaps understandably high# but added that she was encouraged to hear of work done by the health board to train, recruitment and retain staff.#I was also interested to hear about the use of technology here in Shetland of #Attend Anywhere# [which uses Skype technology] and using video conferencing for accessing specialists on the mainland,# Ms Haughey said.NHS Shetland chief executive Ralph Roberts said #positive discussions# had been held with the Scottish government over the festive period #on how we can get support to recognise cost pressures we have had in the past year#.Earlier in the meeting Mr Roberts said good progress had been made in the last year, although he insisted the board was far from complacent.#We met our financial targets last year,# he said. #We have a small underspend and that was after we made some very signicant savings of over two and a half million pounds worth.#Mr Robertson said that meant the board could continue to invest in services where it needed to...

title: shetlands broadband among the worst
story: .The consumer affairs publication analysed speed checker data in all  Scottish council areas as well as England and Wales.At three megabits per second Orkney was found to have the slowest speeds in the country. Shetland came second from bottom in Scotland and third-last in the UK with speeds of .Mbps.The fastest speeds in Scotland are found in areas including West Dumbartonshire , Inverclydeand Dundee . Even the Western Isles, at .Mbps, has speeds nearly twice as fast as Shetland.List MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston said that the report highlighted a need for government investment in Shetland#s infrastructure.The Conservative member for the Highlands and Islands said: #I am disappointed to see Shetland lagging so far behind the rest of the country in broadband speeds. Shetland is getting a poor deal and it is rightly a matter of real concern for people here in the islands and across the Highlands and Islands.#I recognise Shetland’s unique geography, but to fulfil its own commitments the Scottish government must make it a priority to investment in the islands’ infrastructure – including broadband connectivity.#Paul Wheelhouse, minister for connectivity and the islands, said: #This report highlights what we already know – that it is more challenging to deliver and upgrade broadband infrastructure in rural areas.#The Scottish government has vowed to make sure all of Scotland has access to superfast broadbandby . Mr Wheelhouse said that  per cent of homes and businesses in Scotland already have access to superfast broadband. managing director of home products and services, said: #It’s incredibly frustrating that so many Scots are still struggling to get a good broadband connection when so many of us rely heavily on the internet to carry out important everyday tasks.#The Scottish Government must now press ahead with plans to provide  per cent of the homes in Scotland with a decent broadband connection and make sure that no one is at a disadvantage because of where they live.#..
