title: Atonement for strong Malone as ‘Hinch falter
story: NEW Year, but same old faces as Ballynahinch took on Malone for the third time in just over a month.They won two close games in December, but travelled to Gibson Park in the knowledge that the East Belfast men would be almost at full strength and a dferent proposition at home.Ballynahinch were able to put out a strong side with Tommy OrsquoToole coming into the front row in the absence of Kyle McCall and Bradley Luney partnering John Donnan in the engine room.Malone forced some early pressure after a nice break and chip ahead from Callum Smith. The resulting m scrum led to a succession of drives for the line and when the ball was recycled a loose pass missed its intended target, but Rory Campbell took the ball smartly on the bounce to score in the corner for an early Malone lead.After Paddy Wright missed a long-range penalty, Ballynahinch earned an excellent attacking position with a m line out following an excellent Ross Adair touch-finder. The line out was won, but Malone forced a crucial turnover and the chance went begging.Both sides continued to be careless in possession in a niggly match, which was low on quality.On  minutes a Malone breakdown penalty gave lsquoHinch a chance to drive for the line and as they progressed, Malone blatantly killed the ball and could count themselves lucky not to receive a yellow. Wright slotted the penalty to close the gap to two points.Following a Malone penalty miss, lsquoHinch botched their own line out allowing the home side to pile into the . Zack McCall was penalised for offside as Malone looked to sweep the ball wide and was given a yellow card. Malone then scored from a tap penalty to take a - half-time lead.The second half followed a similar pattern to the first with Ballynahinch going further behind to another try from the prolic Campbell after another lsquoHinch mistake on their own line out.Ross Adair reduced the arrears on  minutes with a converted try to put lsquoHinch in bonus point territory and the away side belatedly roused themselves to pile the pressure on Malone during the final ten minutes.However, the home defence held and lsquoHinch had to settle for a point, earned largely through the woes of the Malone place kicker, who failed to land any of his attempts on goal.A disappointing start to  for the locals and they will need to be more accurate this week as Ballymena come to Ballymacarn Park.Malone Ballynahinch AIL DIVISION B.prettyPhoto

title: Ballygowan’s Emma hoping to make waves at Abu Dhabi Special Olympics
story: A BALLYGOWAN swimmer is hoping to make a big splash when she goes to the Middle East in March.Twenty three year-old Emma Carlisle will be going for gold when she swims for Ireland at the  Special Olympics World Summer Games in Abu Dhabi.Emma is one of seven athletes from Co Down included in the -strong Team Ireland squad for the Games which take place over March -.Newry is well represented with four athletes selected. They are equestrian athlete Megan McElherron , Fergal Gregory , who will take part in the kayaking events, and swimmers Connor McCloreyand Peadar Connolly .Amy Wattersand Gemma OrsquoKeefe , both from Bangor, will compete as part of the Team Ireland ladiesrsquo basketball team.The road to Abu Dhabi started four years ago. This week, the final preparations began in earnest with the official launch of Team Ireland for the  World Games.Abu Dhabi  will be the largest sporting and humanitarian event in the world this year. Supported by a volunteer management team of , Team Ireland will join , Special Olympics athletes from  countries.Team Ireland athletes from right across the island of Ireland will compete in a total of  sports mdash athletics, badminton, basketball, bocce, bowling, equestrian, football, golf, gymnastics, kayaking, swimming and table tennis.Supporters and sponsors caught up with the athletes for the official launch of the squad on Friday night in Dublin, ahead of their last residential Team Ireland training session this weekend. The  athletes travelled to Dublin to train together and ensure that they are ready to take on their biggest sporting challenge yet.Emma McMenamin, Head of Delegation for Team Ireland, said: ldquoThese athletes are extremely focused and determined and like any athlete facing into a major competition, they are putting % into their training.ldquoIt was great to see how excited the athletes are to be part of this huge event. To represent Team Ireland and compete on the world stage in Abu Dhabi is a big honour and one these Special Olympics athletes are not taking lightly.Special Olympics Ireland is a sports organisation and charity that supports children and adults with intellectual disabilities, right across the island of Ireland.As the countdown to the World Games gets under way, the organisation is calling on the business community and iniduals in Northern Ireland to help raise much-needed funds to send the athletes to Abu Dhabi.To cover the cost of sending Team Ireland to the Games, Special Olympics needs to raise just over pound, per athlete.Shaun Cassidy, Regional Director Special Olympics Ulster: said: ldquoIt is a great honour for each and every Ulster athlete that has been selected for Team Ireland, having worked so hard over the past three years to qualy for these Games and to compete at international level and represent Team Ireland in Abu Dhabi.ldquoWith just over  days to go, the excitement is mounting, and we would encourage local businesses to come forward and put their support behind these dedicated athletes.ldquoCompanies large and small across Northern Ireland can show their support for our Team Ireland athletes by visiting www.specialolympics.ie and getting involved in our Support an Athlete campaign.ldquoThe business community has been so supportive and we are calling on you again to play your part and help make the dreams of our athletes come true.For further information about Team Ireland and the Support an Athlete programme, visit www.specialolympics.ie.To keep up to date with Team Irelandrsquos preparations for the Special Olympics World Summer Games in Abu Dhabi, follow Special Olympics Ireland and Special Olympics Ulster on Twitter, @SOIreland and @SO_Ulster and Facebook, facebook SpecialOlympicsIreland and Facebook SpecialOlympicsUlster and follow the hashtags, #TeamIreland and #PlayYourPart..prettyPhoto

title: Book delves into tales  and history in Co Down
story: A NEW book looking at often fascinating, sometimes obscure but always entertaining facts about Co Down has been written by a Ballynahinch woman.Author Doreen McBride has put together a charming collection of little-known quirky anecdotes entitled The Little Book of County Down.While it may be little, it packs a big punch and asks some questions that would challenge even the most knowledgeable Co Down people.Have you given anyone a lsquoKillinchy Waistcoatrsquo lately  Would you know what it was, evenyou have Did you know Charles de Gaullersquos ancestors came from Loughinisland  In fact you can still visit their graves.Did you also know the man who designed the Titanic and lost his le on its ill-fated maiden voyage came from Comber And Errol Flynn, the swashbuckling, hard-drinking, rsquos Hollywood idol grew up for a time at lsquoKurrajongrsquo mdash a humble lsquoTazmanian-lookingrsquo dwelling in Kilclief.Doreen has included all kinds of folklore tales, such as the stories behind Maggiersquos Leap and Dollyrsquos Brae, as well as much  besides.You will also learn about the man famed for introducing drinking chocolate to Britain mdash Sir Hans Sloane, who was born in Killyleagh. He was a royal physician and his lersquos work made up the greater part of the British Museum collection which opened in .If your surname is Savage, Martel, Ridal, Copeland or Jordan, yoursquoll be intrigued to know that your early Norman ancestors built strong castles to protect themselves against attacks from locals in the th century.John de Courcy, a prominent Anglo-Norman caused far-reaching change in Ireland around this time. He defeated the Irish at Downpatrick and gave these families who followed him large estates.Their strongholds were no match, however, for the energy and enthusiasm of the locals and eventually it was easier for them to adopt Irish manners and dress and conform to the customs of Down.According to Irish custom, land didnrsquot belong to the king mdash it belonged to the people and usually went to the strongest chieftain. The residents are reported to have disliked taxes, not much change there down the centuries.McBride dedicates a chapter to the United Irishman mdash immortalised as lsquoThe Man From God Knows Wherersquo mdash who was hanged outside Downpatrick Gaol .And where would society beit wasnrsquot for the humble rubber tyre, whose inventor, John Boyd Dunlop, worked for several years in his brotherrsquos veterinary practice in Downpatrick.Of course no book on the history of Co Down would be complete without a chapter on some of our ghosts and ghouls.McBride has included some of the most interesting. The book tells the story of Noel Killen, originally from Loughinisland, who rode his bike passed the old derelict Ballydugan Flour Mill, near Downpatrick, when he was a young lad and dreamt of restoring it.His dream came true. By virtue of his hard work he recaptured the millrsquos former glory and turned it into an award-winning wedding venue, complete with three happy ghosts who attend weddings and bring luck.Therersquos a Presbyterian minister who loiters around the basement and sometimes appears on the ground floor in the corner near the fire. Then there is Bobby, who danders across the first floor. He can be unpredictable as he is often said to slam the occasional door.Then there is the young girl dressed in sackcloth who loves to dance. She can sometimes be seen to be dancing to the music provided at the wedding breakfast.The book also notes the fable of Maggie who leapt across a deep chasm between the clfs near Newcastle in a bid to outrun a group of soldiers while carrying a basket of stolen birdrsquos eggs.Not an egg was broken in her successful attempt to clear the clf and she lived to see a ripe old age. Her ghost is said to loiter around the area know to locals as Maggiersquos Leap.Every quirky illustration that appears in the -page book has been drawn by the hand of the multi-talented Doreen.bull The Little Book of County Down can can be found on Amazon and in all good book stores..prettyPhoto

title: Children and senior citizens  together in residential day
story: ITrsquoS not often children have the opportunity to show others how to do something but thatrsquos exactly what happens when pupils from St Nicholasrsquo Primary School in Ardlgass Primary School visited a residential home for the elderly.P children from the school were chosen to work alongside residents of Ardview Residential Home in a cross-generational art project with local artist Fionnuala Duffin.The children began twice-weekly sessions before the Chrismas break and will continue until the mid term break.Funding for the project came from the Play Resource Centre. The first week saw pupils and residents sketch the iconic tourist attractions of Ardglass, including the golf course and the harbour.The sketches will be presented as a three-metre long collage in which the sea and the sky will be added using some bright blue tissue paper and cotton wool. It will be exhibited in the residential home and the primary school so that as many people as possible can get a chance to admire it.P teacher Mary McGrady, who is leading the project, said the boys and girls relished the opportunity and worked ldquofantastically well with the residents.ldquoIt was heart-warming to see the smiles on the residentsrsquo faces as they chat to each other and share stories, she said. The children really look forward to working on theproject with their new friends each week.ldquoThe residents love to see the children coming. They have started to teach them songs they knew when they were small and the children sing along with them.ldquoThe residents also tell the children stories of the people who once lived in the village and it is heartening to watch them interact the way they do. Itrsquos great craic.Mrs McGrady said she was proud of each and every one of the pupils.ldquoThe children are a credit to themselves, our school and their parents, she added..prettyPhoto

title: Co Down named in top 100  sustainable destination list
story: STUNNING Strangford Lough and the majestic Mourne mountains helped Co Down secure a place on a prestigious list of leading tourism areas.The county is the only destination in the UK and Ireland to secure a place on the Sustainable Destinations Top  list which is organised by Green Destinations and a partnership of  organisations.The list celebrates the efforts of established and emerging tourism destinations for responsible and sustainable tourism and in addition to achieving a place in the top , the county also achieved a gold award for its tourism offering.Nominators had to provide extensive information on their destination and its efforts to make itself and its stakeholders more sustainable for the benefit of visitors, local communities and the world.Candidate destinations also had to clary what they have been doing to comply with the  globally recognised criteria of the Green Destinations Standard.The Top  initiative aims to recognise tourism destinations that have worked hard to make a dference and take sustainability seriously. Nevertheless, no destination is fully sustainable and in all selected destinations important issues remain to be solved.Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairman Mark Murnin said the organisation was delighted that Co Down had been recognised by Green Destinations.ldquoThis outstanding achievement was only possible thanks to the joint commitment of tourism businesses in the region, the council and its partners, he said. ldquoIt gives us signicant marketing advantage as we promote the region in .Stuart Park, lead sustainability assessor for Green Tourism mdash who acted as a mentor for the Co Down application mdash said that achieving a spot in the top , as well as the prestigious gold award, ldquoare well deserved recognition for Co Down.He said: ldquoCo Down has put an emphasis on more sustainable options through outstanding walking and cycling routes throughout the Mournes, Ring of Gullion and around Strangford Lough, unique local food and drink, rich wildle, history and culture.ldquoSupporting this is a well-developed infrastructure with effective waste management practices, low carbon travel options as well as excellent visitor experiences and green accommodation providers.Mr Park said the local authorities, tourism businesses and ious partner organisations had worked well together to demonstrate the strengths of the county.He added: ldquoThey put together a very strong case for the Green Destination award which combined strong policies and plans with an enthusiastic and knowledgeable destination team. It was clear that an effort was being made to reduce the impacts of the destination while enhancing the visitor experience.ldquoIt is no surprise that this has helped increase tourism to Co Down, while the region is now attracting some world-class sporting events as well as location filming for prestigious television and cinema productions.Ards and North Down Council chairman Richard Smart said the region had proven itself through rigorous assessment to be a leading sustainable destination.ldquoThis is a credit to all partners and will give yet another opportunity to highlight the authenticity of our visitor experience, he added.bull Co Down will receive its certicate in March during ITB Berlin, the worldrsquos leading travel trade show..prettyPhoto

title: Country and western dancers on top of the world
story: A GROUP of local dancers have ed home after striking gold in the country and western world dance championships in America.Three girls from the Kasana Dance Studio in Downpatrick competed in the United Country Western Dance CouncilWorld Championships in Nashville, Tennessee.Aisling Vaughan won two titles in the Newcomer Primary Pro-am and Newcomer Primary Classic Solo categories.Niamh Fionda won the Newcomer Classic Solo Youth category and was second in the Pro-am Newcomer Youth section.Dance teacher Kathryn Patterson was named world champion in the Intermediate Open Classic Solo ision.Kasana Dancers would like to thank their sponsors, Philip Polly, from Cosy Roof Ltd, and Steven Vaughan, from Autozone Downpatrick, for their very generous sponsorship..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the  Down Recorder%2C January 23%2C 1979
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash Staff at Downpatrickrsquos hospitals paraded through the town yesterday in support of a pay claim by their union, the Confederation of Health Service Employees.The action was one of several stoppages which have been taking place throughout the province this week and the march was attended by top union bosses.COHSE is pressing for a basic pay increase to pound per week and has stressed that industrial action could be stepped up until demands are met by the Government.Off-duty nursing staff, ancillary staff and general staff including catering and domestic workers began their protest walk at the Downshire Hospital and travelled through Downpatrickrsquos streets for more than an hour.Several hundred members of staff walked from the hospital down Edward Street and Irish Street, along Market Street, up St Patrickrsquos Avenue and then back to the Downshire grounds.A spokesman for COHSE who attended the march warned that action in Downpatrick could be followed by further pressure.ldquoThere may be further action taken unless the Government sees fit to come up with a pound basic wage at least, he said. ldquoThese people are grossly underpaid and the Government is going to have to face that fact.Hospital works were not the only people involved in -hours stoppages. Also affected were Department of the Environment workers including the Strangford Ferry operators. The ferry was out of service throughout the day and commuters were forced to travel to their destinations via Newtownards.Caretakers and canteen staff at local schools were also called out by their union, the National Union of Public Employees, and bin collections grounded to a halt when bin men withdrew services.DUNDRUM mdash Department of the Environment officials have been called in to deal with a row over indiscriminate dumping on a site for new playing fields in Dundrum.A decision to call in planning experts was taken at a meeting of Down Council this week after councillors received a letter of complaint from a resident.Mrs Elizabeth Megaughey complained that no control had been exercised at the site after a wall had been broken down and she felt that nothing would stop indiscriminate dumping until the site was closed down.The site is owned by Dundrum Sports Committee and is located at Old Road on the Newcastle end of the town. The committee raised money in a year-long campaign to help convert waste ground into badly-needed playing fields.CROSSGAR mdash A Crossgar businessman flies out to the Middle East tomorrow morning to complete negotiations for a lucrative pound million contract to find water in the drought-stricken Yemen Republic.Mr William Quinn, who owns a water well-drilling firm based in Crossgar, will be accompanied on his amazing journey by two consultant engineers and an international overseas manager of a firm which has been dealing with Middle East countries for the past  years.Mr Quinn told the Recorder yesterday that his negotiations could lead to the creation of over  jobs for the Crossgar area. If terms are agreed Mr Quinnrsquos Drillwell firm will begin drilling  bore holes as soon as possible to find water.The invitation to the Crossgar firm has come from Prince Bander Ben Khalid, who will be financing the operationit goes ahead.Mr Quinn explained: ldquoPrince Bander, through a consultant engineer, invited us to negotiate a major contract to bore  hones in the village of Sana in North Yemen to find much-needed water.ldquoIt may mean getting more machinery and taking on up to  more men to complete the contract in two years, but providing arrangements are made satisfactorily I will accept.ldquoThe specialists and myself fly out from London tomorrow to begin negotiations and they will advise me on the finer points of the contract. If all goes well I will be ing soon with good news.NEWCASTLE mdash A new Clerk of Petty Sessions was welcomed to Newcastle Court on Monday.Although Mr Stephen McMillan has been in the legal profession for some time, he has now taken up the post as clerk for the Newcastle, Castlewellan and Kilkeel areas.Mr McMillan was welcomed by the resident magistrate, Mr John Petrie, Inspector McComiskey, of Newcastle RUC, and Mr Denis Kearney, solicitor.ARDGLASS mdash This yearrsquos Ardglass Festival programme has been increased by four days due to the huge success of the event last year mdash and the organisers have promised that it will be a massive family attraction.The programme will run from July - and it is estimated that the entertainment-packed event will cost at least pound, to get off the ground.The theme of the festival will be lsquoThe Ardglass Fishing Industry mdash Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow.rsquo One of the men behind the festival, Mr Dermot Curran, said that the reaction to last yearrsquos event was ldquofantastic.ldquoWe have increased theof the programme by four days because of the success of the  event, he said. ldquoIn fact, we have already had inquiries from families in the Isle of Man and England who were here last year and are keen to come back.Mr Curran stressed that continued assistance is needed from Down Council and local traders. ldquoWe want this to be a big family affair, he continued. ldquoWe would welcome help from anyone interested in making the festival full of fun and entertainment.The festival committee for this year comprises Pat Irvine, chairman George McGrath, treasurer James Murray, secretary Dermot Curran, festival organiser Margaret Milligan, Pauline Smith, Brian Gill, John McGrath, M Cahir, L Kelly, James Rooney and Captain R Fitzsimons.CARRYDUFF mdash A Carryduff girl was given the chance of a transatlantic link-up for a special hotline of love.Donna Todd, from Ivanhoe Avenue, stole the heart of Texan pilot Jim Kendall at a Belfast discotheque last November and frantic bids to trace her finally ended when a daily newspaperrsquos story caught her attention.Nineteen year-old Donna confirmed she was the girl that the Texan, now back in his home in Houston, had fallen for when she was able to described what clothes she was wearing that night.The newspaper, in typical Cupid-style, arranged for her to telephone the pilot in a special link-up to his home , miles away.ldquoHe asked me to go out and visit him in Texas this summer and I said that I might, providing I brought a friend with me, Donna said. ldquoHe had no objections mdash as long as I didnrsquot bring a boyfriend.The couple have agreed to write to each other and hopefully to fulfil that meeting in the summer.KILLYLEAGH mdash Mr Eric Gourley received gts from teaching colleagues at Killyleagh High School at a recent farewell dinner in his honour.Mr Gourley was a member of staff at the school for  years and was actively involved in after-school activities, particularly the twice nightly youth club based at the school. He has now been appointed Divisional Youth Officer.The presentation was made by Mr David Coey, the schoolrsquos vice-principal.CASTLEWELLAN mdash One of the South Eastern Education and Library Boardrsquos most eagerly awaited libraries in Castlewellanrsquos restored Market House opens its doors to the public next week. The current library will close tonight for the last time.Perhaps the happiest person at the opening will be Mrs Maureen Keenan, the librarian for the past seven years. She will be delighted to have such a vast range of services on offer compared to what she had in the limited space of the health clinic.Mrs Keenan and her three assistants, Mrs Fionnuala Young, Mrs Georgina Greer and Mrs Mary Boden, already have most of the new stock on display in the Market House. They have a tremendous range of interests for children, who are usually the first through the door in most cases of modern libraries being opened..prettyPhoto

title: Hazzard calls for Presidential vote rights in North
story: SOUTH Down MP Chris Hazzard believes that passing a referendum on the extension of Presidential voting rights will ensure citizens in Northern Ireland are not left behind by the Irish Government.He was part of a Sinn Feacutein delegation which met recently with the Taacutenaiste, Simon Coveney. In addition to the voting issue, other topics included Brexit and restoring power sharing at Stormont.Mr Hazzard said the upcoming referendum on extending votes in presidential elections will be a ldquopositive opportunity to affirm the governmentrsquos commitment to never again to leave citizens in the North behind.He continued: ldquoIt can also provide Ireland and our global diaspora with a tangible and positive link to each other. Monday of this week marked the anniversary of An Cheacutead Daacuteil mdash the First Daacuteil mdash so the upcoming poll announced by the government can afford Ireland the opportunity of having yet another truly national election, ensuring that all of our people have an equal say in what is an important office and expression of Irish le.Mr Hazzard said in  it was crucially important that Irish political, community, civic and cultural organisations in South Down, across the north of Ireland and overseas, are engaged and prepared for what described as this ldquomomentous vote.He added: ldquoThere is an onus now on the Irish government to ensure they facilitate the required process to ensure this crucial and timely referendum will be won in the most collaborative and positive way possible..prettyPhoto

title: Interested parties sought for tearooms in Tollymore
story: PLANS to enhance Tollymore Forest Parkrsquos reputation as one of the provincersquos leading visitor attractions take an important step forward next month.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is seeking expressions of interest from the private sector to utilise the Clanbrassil Barn located at the Bryansford Gate entrance to the stunning park and the former tearooms close to the main car park area. Both buildings are listed.The forest park is owned and managed by the Forest Service and with the local authority putting tourism at the top of its agenda, both organisations are keen to see Tollymore flourish.A formal call for entrepreneurs to lodge an expression of interest in both facilities is due to be ratied at the February meeting of the local authorityrsquos Economic, Tourism and Regeneration Committee.In recent times, the first floor of the two storey Clanbrassil Barn was used as an exhibition space but has been closed for  years. There are also toilets and an education centre on the ground floor while the main building itself was renovated in .The tearooms mdash located between the main and overflow car parks mdash is another two-storey building.A cafe was previously located on the upper floor, with a toilet, shop and storage facilities on the ground floor. The tearooms have not been opened since  with the first floor of the building connected to the overflow car park via an elevated walkway.The external fabric of this building also underwent major repair work in  which included the refurbishment of the foot bridge.Mournes councillor Willie Clarke has weighed in with his support for new cafeacute facilities at the hugely popular forest park.He has been lobbying for such high quality facilities at the tourist attraction at the foothills of the Mournes and is pleased the issue will be discussed next month.ldquoI am pleased the local council is seeking expressions of interest from interested parties for service provision in the Clanbrassil Barn and the tearooms at the forest park, he said.ldquoIt has taken a while to get to this stage but this will be fabulous facility for visitors and locals alike. The addition of a high quality cafeacute will greatly enhance the visitor experience that the forest park offers.Cllr Clarke said the park is set to become an even more attractive location, with the Forest Service buildings being brought back into use.Describing this as a ldquolong overdue development he said it was another key step in the local authorityrsquos ongoing work to make forest parks even more enjoyable for those who use them.ldquoThe new cafeacute provision will only make the forest park even more attractive to visitors and we continue to work to enhance our forest parks and open spaces.ldquoNow that we are embarking on this new partnership with the Forest Service, all of this is being done to improve the visitor experience in our forest parks, he said.Cllr Clarke added: ldquoThe planned development will help attract a greater footfall to Tollymore during the off-peak season and as such, bring great local economic benefit to our area.ldquoThis has all been a long time coming and we hope the partnership with the Forest Service will be the start of potentially bigger projects in the future..prettyPhoto

title: Local schools in cup derby
story: TWO local schools go head-to-head on Friday in a bid to reach the MacLarnon Cup semi-finals.All eyes will be focused on the highly-anticipated quarter-final clash between St Patrickrsquos High School, Downpatrick, and St Malachyrsquos High School, Castlewellan, on at St Colmanrsquos Park, Drumaness.This encounter will serve as a nice aperit for Downrsquos opening game in Division  of the NFL when they face Laios at Pairc Esler on Saturday night with supporters banking on a new era of hope under manager Paddy Tally.The county stars of the future will strut their stuff on Friday when the rival schools, both former All-Ireland winners at U- level, clash for the third time in three years.St Patrickrsquos would appear on paper to have the stronger , which includes several Down Minors from last season and players who should make an impact for James McCartan this year.However, never write off a team from St Malachyrsquos as they thrive on adversity and being tagged underdogs as they have proved so often in the past.St Patrickrsquos really have a star-studded squad. Led by Downpatrickrsquos Ronan Murphy, who has held down a regular starting place in the RGU team that plays in Division  of the ACFL, the Red High didnrsquot start their campaign that well.A - to - defeat in the first group game to Our Lady and St Patrickrsquos College, Knock, put the dampners on the schoolrsquos high expectations.However, much improved performances followed with a - to - win over St. Patrickrsquos, Keady and a - to - win over St. Louisrsquo, Ballymena, sending the Red High to the top of their group.The squad is built around a strong, solid team ethic with a number of players proving to be extremely versatile in a number of positions.Notable players thus far have been dual stars Tim Prenter and Ciaran Watson, who have both picked up Ulster Schoolsrsquo GAA Hurling All Stars this year.Ballygalget clubman Watson also made history by becoming the first winning captain of the An Dun Mageean Cup side last November and Prenter, who plays hurling for Ballygalget and football for Downpatrick, was a member of the Down senior hurling side that won the McGurk Cup last week.Niall Laverty, from Saul, was a key player in his clubrsquos senior side that secured the All County Division  title in .Ruairi OrsquoHare, also from Saul, is a talented soccer player, turning out for Linfield Swts and Northern Ireland Schoolboys mdash he was in the Northern Ireland Schoolboys team that took on Australia last night.Tom Smyth, Brandon Boyd and Peter McMullan were in last yearrsquos county minor squad and in Eoin Rooney, Ryan Wynn, Drew Barnes, Tom Savage, Oran Cunningham, Jack Harbinson, Ruairi Quinn and Aodhan Harney they have a group of highly-talented and motivated players.St Malachyrsquos also a possess a number of players who have excelled for their clubs and they will look to Dromararsquos Brendan McKey, a Schoolsrsquo All Starwinner, Liatroimrsquos Conor McAnuty and Kilcoorsquos Shealan Johnston.This is only St Malachyrsquos third year playing in the MacLarnon Cup and they have reached the quarter-finals on merit.They started with draws against Inis Eoghain and SS Castleblayney before beating St Pius X, Magherafelt.They were beaten by a good Cathair Dhoire outft, but had done enough to progress to the last eight.St Malachyrsquos will rely on Kilcoorsquos Jamie McKee in goal and he will have support from defenders Tyrone Fegan, Jonathan McVeigh, Gareth Fitzpatrick, Conor McAnulty, Eoin McCrickard and Tiarnan Fettes.This unit give few scores away and they love nothing better than ruining reputations.Brendan McKey and Daire McVeigh should man the midfield berths and they will keep Ryan OrsquoHiggins, Caolan Burns, Anthony Morgan, Daniel McKibben, Matthew Carvill, and the extremely dangerous Shealan Johnston supplied with decent ball.Johnston is St Malachyrsquos attacking jewel in the crown and he will keep the Red High defenders on their toes, but getting scores will be another matter.St Patrickrsquos squad: Ronan Murphy , Ryan Wynn , Eoin Rooney , Tom Smyth , Ruairi Quinn , Tim Prenter , Drew Barnes , Tom Savage , Oran Cunningham , Tony Carson , Jack Harbinson , Conor Murray , Peter McMullan , Brandon Boyd , Tom McDonald , Dara McDonald , Peter Kearney , Ciaran Watson , Niall Laverty , Ruairi OrsquoHare , Aodhan Harney , Ronan Conor , Dermot Donaldson , Lorcan Guiness , Eoin Maginn , Tomas Fettes , Paul Tempany , Rory Mullan , Caolan Murray .St Malachyrsquos squad: Jamie McKee , Tyrone Fegan , Jonathan McVeigh , Gareth Fitzpatrick , Conor McAnulty , Eoin McCrickard , Tiernan Fettes , Daire McVeigh , Brendan McKey , Anthony Morgan , Ryan OrsquoHiggins , Daniel McKibben , Mathew Carvill , Shealan Johnston , Caolan Burns , Sean Og McCusker , Jervis Og McCaul , Luke Clarke , Eoin McEvoy , Joseph OrsquoBoyle , Patrick Kelly-McEvoy , Shea Croskery ..prettyPhoto

title: Meeting to prevent babies sent away for post mortem
story: LOCAL health campaigners are seeking a meeting with the most senior civil servant at the Department of Health to discuss the controversial plan to send babies to England for post-mortems.The decision to seek talks with Permanent Secretary Richard Pengelly, was taken at last weekrsquos meeting of the Down Community Health Committee following a passionate address by one of the grouprsquos leading members, Anne Trainor.Mrs Trainorrsquos daughter, Joanne, sadly passed away in , aged four and a half. She suffered from the heart condition Tricuspid Atresia.Mrs Trainor has described the decision to send babies to the Alder Hey Childrenrsquos Hospital in Liverpool after the provincersquos paediatric pathologist retired as ldquoinhumane.She believes thatpriority was given to funding and enticement for the training of pathologists, post-mortems could continue to be carried out on a regional basis.In addition, Mrs Trainor believes the possibility of pathologists travelling to Northern Ireland periodically from England, Scotland, Wales and further afield could be considered.Addressing last weekrsquos meeting, Mrs Trainor described the decision to perform post-mortems in Liverpool as ldquosickening and immoral and argued health officials should have done more to continue the service, knowing that a senior pathologist was retiring.ldquoFor women who have had a miscarriage or whose baby dies, it is the single worst thing that is ever going to happen in your le, she said.ldquoYou will lose parents, aunts and uncles, husbands and wives, but you will never experience the pain and heartbreak of losing a child. For health officials to suggest that a child is wrapped up like a package and sent across the water for a post mortem is cruel.ldquoI am not sure what provision would be in place for parents to accompany the child, but to send them on such a journey is heartbreaking. The entire family circle suffers when something like this happens.Mrs Trainor said the decision to hold post-mortems in England was the ldquosingle, most horrying thing she has ever heard.She continued: ldquoThe health service never ceases to amaze me and once again due to a lack of foresight, planning and finance, we find ourselves in what is an unforgivable situation, she continued, commending Newry, Mourne and Down Council for recently highlighting the post mortem issue.ldquoI am not the only person who has lost a child, quite a few people have and there are those who would join me to meet with Mr Pengelly to explain that sending babies across the water for post mortem is just not acceptable.The health campaigner believes there must be a paediatric pathologist who is prepared to provide cover in Northern Ireland, admitting she would also be in favour of an all island service.ldquoSending babies away is not an option and while an all island option is better than sending babies to Liverpool, I believe we must have this service provided here, she declared. ldquoWe need to meet with the Permanent Secretary as soon as possible on this vital issue.Committee chairman Eamonn McGrady said it was his understanding that there were strains on pathology services across the province due to workforce issues.ldquoIssues like this happen over a period of time and you sometimes wonder just how much attention is given to the planning aspect, he said.ldquoHow do officials plan for the future  It is not just enough to commission a report on the issue and put it in the bottom drawer and announce you are several thousand nurses short when you have had ample opportunity over several years to train more.South Down MLA Colin McGrath, who attended last weekrsquos meeting in Downpatrick, said holding post-mortems in England ldquowill bring untold pain and suffering to families in their darkest hour.He added: ldquoWe must do everything within our power to try and bring a resolution to this resource issue including examining a North-South approach. Local people have sought a meeting with Department of Health officials on this matter and I will be happy to pursue and facilitate this.ldquoThere is a need for such a crucially important service for parents and indeed the wider family circle to be delivered regionally.Three weeks ago, local politicians called on the Permanent Secretary to reduce the ldquoalready enormous burden from parents suffering from bereavement and come up with a better solution than sending babies to Liverpool.Politicians said they were not averse to an all island service, insisting the reinstatement of the Belfast-based paediatric pathologist who retied is also vitally important moving forward..prettyPhoto

title: New £217k play park welcome boost for Meadowlands estate
story: MEADOWLANDS estate in Downpatrick is at last to get a new play park costing pound,.Work on the park should start within weeks and be ready by the end of March.A proposal to proceed with the scheme was approved by Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Active and Healthy Communities Committee on Monday night.The new park is a joint project with the council and Downpatrick Neighbourhood Renewal with % funding from the Department of the Communities.The council will be responsible for managing its construction and its maintenance.The new park is to be located in front of Drumcloon Walk and adjacent to the Quoile Crescent housing development.According to the Northern Ireland Neighbourhood Information Service statistics, Meadowlands is ranked th out of  areas of high health deprivation.The need for the park has also been supported by statistics from the Northern Ireland Research and Information Agency which show that there are  children under the age of  living in the Quoile Ward area who could avail of the park.It is also hoped that the park will help with the regeneration of the area and improve its overall look.The siting of the park was moved after some local concern was expressed that it would too close to pensionersrsquo homes in Drumcloon Park.Meadowlands Community Association, which was formed with help from local councillor Cadogan Enright, last week welcomed the move and the fact that the council listened to its representations.At Mondayrsquos meeting, Cllr Billy Walker proposed that the committee agree to go ahead with the park.He said: ldquoI really welcome this play park, as will the residents, he said. ldquoBeing the last chairman of the old district council, I know that a park for Meadowlands was a legacy issue.ldquoThere is real need for this as Meadowlands is one of the most deprived areas in the Downpatrick DEA and itrsquos to good see that that hard work is at last bearing fruit.Cllr Cadogan, who seconded the proposal, added: ldquoI am delighted that this play park can go ahead as I have been working with the residents for years and itrsquos at last getting over the line..prettyPhoto

title: New amenity centre set for spring opening
story: DOWNPATRICKrsquoS new ultra-modern civic amenity centre could open as early as the spring, council officials have confirmed.The new facility at Flying Horse Road will replace the existing centre at nearby Cloonagh Road, which continues to struggle with the increasing demands being placed upon it.Over the Christmas and New Year holiday period, the centre was forced to close early due to the volume of waste.The early closure annoyed many ratepayers with council officials confident the new centre mdash which is signicantly larger mdash will be able to handle more recyclable material.Over recent years, Newry, Mourne and Down Council has invested signicant sums building new civic amenity sites in Ballynahinch and Castlewellan, with the Flying Horse Road facility set to be one of the most modern of its kind.Confirmation that the new Downpatrick centre could open as early as the spring will be given at this eveningrsquos meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Regulatory and Technical Services Committee.There was a delay in building the new facility as a suitable site could not be identied and when work did eventually get underway, progress was temporarily halted as equipment belonging to contractors was targeted by vandals.Downpatrick councillor Dermot Curran has welcomed news then the new centre could open for business as early as the spring.The local authorityrsquos lease of the Cloonagh Road facility has been extended until the end of March but it has been recognised for some time that this facility has passed its sell-by-date.Cllr Curran said it was important Downpatrick had a recycling centre which was fit-for-purpose and could meet the needs of ratepayers across a wide area.He said the facility was not solely used by people in the town. He also hoped the local authority investment in the new site will encourage more people to recycle more of their waste.Cllr Curran continued: ldquoWhile it is taking longer to deliver the new centre than originally envisaged, work is progressing well and I have no doubt that the facility will be a success.ldquoThe investment at the Flying Horse Road site is good news for the town. It is my understanding that the design of the new centre will also ensure it complies with strict health and safety legislation.Cllr Curran also believes the new centre will help the local council meet its recycling targets.He added: ldquoI am assured every effort is being made to have the new centre opened within the next few months to provide a st century recycling facility..prettyPhoto

title: New dawn for Down
story: DOWNrsquoS senior footballers embark on a new journey of hope on Saturday night.Thatrsquos when Paddy Tallyrsquos charges open their NFL Division  campaign with a home game against Laois at Pairc Esler.Regardless of what some Down fans think, a win against newly-promoted Laois is not guaranteed mdash John Sugruersquos side will be no pushovers after winning the Division  final last year in style.In Donie Kingston, Ross Munnelly, Eoin Lowry, John OrsquoLoughlin, Kieran Lillis and Alan Farrell they have the nucleus of a resolute side that will be a real threat to Down.Down have further Division  games against Sligo, Westmeath, Longford, Offaly, Carlow and Louth, and will be hoping to bounce back into Division  after relegation last year.Louth will also be hoping for promotion, while Carlow and Laois will look to build on a positive  campaign which secured promotion from the bottom tier.Itrsquos still anyonersquos guess who Tally will start with on Saturday night.He experimented a lot in the McKenna Cup and must have been pleased with promising performances from Castlewellanrsquos Rory Burns, Warrenpointrsquos Ryan McAleenan, Bredaghrsquos Conor Francis, the McClements brothers, Aaron and Declan, from Loughinisland, Downpatrickrsquos Conor McGrady, Saulrsquos Ciaran Harney, Kilcoorsquos Paul Devlin and Savalrsquos Pat Havern and Danny McCarthy.However, Down will again rely on Caolan Mooney, Brendan McArdle, Gerard Collins, Jerome Johnston, Connaire Harrison and Donal OrsquoHare and they are expected to be the backbone of the side.Definitely missing are the suspended trio of Kevin McKernan, Darren OrsquoHagan and Ryan Johnston, Anthony Doherty and Gerard McGovern, who are both in Australia, Shay Millar, who is taking a break from inter-county football, and midfield colossus Peter Turley, who has retired from the  along with former captain Mark Poland and Aidan Carr.Tally will stick with his bid to unearth fresh talent and continue to experiment ahead of this summerrsquos Ulster Senior Football Championship quarter-final clash with Armagh. Bryansfordrsquos Ruairi Wells, Mayobridgersquos Shane Annett and Saulrsquos Ciaran Harney all caught the eye in the McKenna Cup and they might just be thrown into the cauldron on Saturday night.Tally, who led St Maryrsquos College to Sigerson Cup success two years ago, is only too well aware of the talent in Down and it is now his job to bring those players forward.Downrsquos future lies in the hands of young players like Burrenrsquos Ryan Treanor, Liam Kerr and Steven Fegan, Kilcoorsquos Ceilum Doherty and Miceal Rooney, Saulrsquos Pierce Laverty and Lorcan Harney and Oisin McConvey from Darragh Cross, most of whom are involved in the Sigerson Cup.However, what is also required now is as steady hand on the tiller and Tally will not want to expose too many of his rising stars just yet.That leaves the way open for some of the more experienced players to reaffirm their capabilities and prove their worth to the .Meanwhile, the county hurlers open their NHL Division B campaign with a home game at Pairc Esler, also on Saturday night, against Derry.Ronan Sheehanrsquos new-look side go into the game full of confidence after recently lting the McGurk Cup.The new manager has gambled on youth as being the way forward and he has rising stars in Tim Prenter, Ronan Blair, Ronan Costello and Mark Patterson.Experience will be provided by Conor OrsquoPrey, Caolan Taggart, Conor Woods, Eoin Sands, P J Davidson, Ruairi McCrickard, Paul Sheehan and Cormac Coulter.Sheehan has targeted promotion from Division B and a good run in the Christy Ring Cup this season and he is certainly going the right way about it..prettyPhoto

title: Niamh on the comeback trail
story: MANY of East Downrsquos senior men had fancied entering the Elite International k, the highlight of Saturdayrsquos cross country races at the Billy Neill Centre in Dundonald.They wanted to pit their talents against the cream of the GB athletic fraternity and the rest of the world in the shape of a quartet of African athletes, headed by Rio Olympics k runner-up to Mo Farah, Paul Tanui and the fastest over k in the past year Richard Yator, both from Kenya, and the two young upstarts Birhanu Balew Olympic k finalist in Rio, from Bahrain and Ethiopian Chala Beyo the African Games  Steeplechase gold medallist.Pre-race favourite Paul Tanui was in contention for most of the race, but faded to fourth on the run in as Balewrsquos scintillating sprint for the line left his three companions floundering, with Yator taking second place and Beyo thirdMcKinstry to the foreMark McKinstry, Jimmyrsquos Ten winner in , was the best of the Northern Ireland squad and justied his selection by setting out with the leaders only to have an unfortunate fall in the first lap which left him isolated.However, he is not British Masters cross country champion for nothing and he raised the biggest cheers of the day by holding on to th place mdash it could have been fth or sixth, but for that fall.Decision makingThe EDAC squad opted for the shorter, open mixed race over two laps, k distance and all thoroughly enjoyed the race without feeling short changed by the lesser distance.In fact, it proved a masterly decision as they were able change, freshen up and then to watch the world class action which was displayed before their very eyes.Everyone concerned quickly realised that not only is the spectating side of the tape the best place to see the action when the Africans are in town, but also it prevents the embarrassment and humiliation of being lapped, perhaps several times, by these giants of the sport, as happened to several of the local, very good club runners.Lesson number one: There is absolutely no humiliation factor to be experienced when yoursquore passed by one of these runners ndash as long as yoursquore behind the crowd barrier.Mixed open racePaul Carroll, from Annadale Striders, was the most prominent local in this event and he ran his best race for some time to claim a very satisfying third place. Best of the East Down contingent was Neil Curran, in ninth place, who is improving with every outing, followed by the ever-reliable Martin Willcox , Davy Foster , Gavin Hynds , Paul Lloyd , Gareth Reillyand Donal Smith .This was an excellent warm up race prior to the Intermediate and Masterrsquos Championships which take place on Saturday in Barnettrsquos Park, near Shawrsquos Bridge.Women do well tooThere were lots of positives too in the womenrsquos race, run in conjunction with the menrsquos. Catherine OrsquoConnor ran a strong race and was just outside a podium place by a handful of seconds.Niamh Kellett, still on the recovery after injury, was relieved to run unhampered and to finish pain free in eighth place.Joanne Foster ran her own race, as she always does, finishing strongly inth place, while Kelly Smith , far from being put off by the conditions at her debut at Mallusk last week, not only lined up again on Saturday, but has signed up for three in a row by putting her name down for the intermediate team at Barnettrsquos Demesne.Well done to all and good luck next weekend.Boys and girlsThere were a total of  races on the packed card, starting at .am with the girlsrsquo U- k race in which East Downrsquos All-Ireland silver medal winning team took part. Expectations of another successful day were high and supporters were not disappointed.The team, led by the diminutive Lauren Madine, who was also third overall, was in outstanding form and easily claimed the top team prize. Lucy Foster was seventh and Anna Gardiner th to complete the top scorers and were ably backed up by Kara Trainorand Anna Kearney . Congratulations to all concerned.U- girlsKirsti Foster was the clubrsquos only representative in the U- girlsrsquo race and as ever, she gave a good account of herself, holding off a three-pronged late attack to take an excellent th place.U- boysMackenzie Murray was the only East Down runner in the U- boysrsquo race and as we have come to expect, he ran very well to take th place in the high quality field.Primary school girlsOnce again it was the name Foster which was on the East Down supporters lips as Jodi and Kari took to the twists and turns of the , metre lap round the lake, and when the runners came into view at the start of the long finishing straight it was Jodi who was prominent as she battled all the way to the line, claiming fth place, while just  seconds behind Kari was fairly comfortable in holding onto th position.And boysKieran Trainor had a long wait as his race was number  on the card, but he showed that he had not waited in vain.Showing signs of his blossoming maturity, he bided his time before staging a strong finish to take th place in the  runner , metres event.McGradyrsquos cross countryThe junior cross country series, sponsored by McGrady Financial Services, is a five-race league for five local clubs mdash Newcastle AC, East Down AC, Dromore AC, Burren AC and  Ways AC with one race hosted by each of the clubs who take part.The race, hosted by EDAC, takes place in Delamont, which is a great venue, but last year in this same month, the event could not be held due to the waterlogged state of the ground, so this year East Down AC as host club were determined to deliver and  athletes turned out in perishing cold and seemed to thrive on the muck and the undulating course with an uphill finish to test even the fittest. The joy and enthusiasm of the youngsters is great to see.Gold dustThe results are still being processed and a full report will be produced to pay tribute to the achievements of iniduals and clubs.It has to be said, however, that many of East Downrsquos juniors who had competed at Dundonald the day before turned out again and in my view they all ran noticeably better, seemingly with a new found air of confidence.So, who says that contact with the best, doesnrsquot make the gold dust rub off onto our children ThanksIn the meantime, we would like to thank parents of all involved for bringing their offspring and giving up part of their weekend.In particular we thank the EDAC parents who turned up early to set up or who helped with registration, timing, marshalling or who stayed behind to clear up.Without their support the event could not take place. Credit is also due to the coaches and senior members of the club for their part in the planning of operations.This weekendItrsquos NI and Ulster Intermediate and Masters Championships races in Barnettrsquos Park on Saturday, beginning at pm.Please, ladies in particular, note the revised schedule as due to the numbers involved the intermediate ladiesrsquo race will be a separate race at pm, and will not be combined with theMasters Women, as originally planned.See you there..prettyPhoto

title: Reception celebrates 45 years’ service
story: THE contribution of the provincersquos longest serving councillor to the district and its people was recognised at a civic reception in his honour last weekend.Dermot Curran has served the people of the district for an incredible  years and his letime of public service recognised by Newry, Mourne and Down Council at a celebratory event at the Millbrook Lodge Hotel in Ballynahinch.Joined by his we Karen, family friends, former and current council colleagues and Northern Ireland Local Government representatives, Cllr Curran was overwhelmed by the good wishes of around  people who attended the event.Also in attendance were representatives from regional and national governments and non-governmental organisations who joined together to celebrate a remarkable achievement.Tributes were paid by current council chairman Mark Murnin, local authority chief executive Liam Hannaway and Northern Ireland Local Government Associationvice-president Fred Donnelly.The council presented him with a beautul James G Miles painting of Ballyhornan beach where he revealed he played as a boy, while Cllr Curranrsquos SDLP colleagues presented him with a portrait oh himself by Killyleagh artist Leo Casement.Cllr Murnin said his council colleague has been dedicated to public service since his first election in , serving two terms as Down Council chairman and then being elected to Newry, Mourne and Down Council in .ldquoOur council has been fortunate to have many hard working and exemplary councillors who strive to make this district a better place to live and work in, he continued. ldquoNo one demonstrates this more clearly than Dermot and during his first term as council chairman, he had the vision to work with councils across Ireland to develop relationships and encourage co-operative projects.ldquoBut we are not the only body to recognise the contribution that Dermot has made to our district. In , he was judged the winner of the Local Government Awards Best Initiative by a Councillor and just last year was presented with the National Association of Councillors Long Service Award.Cllr Murnin said he was ldquoproud to be Cllr Curranrsquos colleague and friend and looked forward to working with him for many years to come.He added: ldquoI believe all councillors look at Dermot with respect and admiration and see him as a great role model. He has witnessed many changes during his years in council, working for the good of the people, representing all communities and working with all political parties.ldquoIn his earlier years, he was not averse to the odd walk-out of the council chamber to emphasise his point. Dermot is a pillar of the council and deserving of our wholehearted congratulations on his milestone achievement.Mrs Donnelly described the Downpatrick area councillor as a ldquobreath of fresh air in the debating chamber, on NILGA and other bodies.She said that  years after his first election, he continued to seek solutions, fairness and co-operation, admitting that he always somehow managed to squeeze in a mention for his home village of Ardglass.ldquoDermot always seeks a fairness approach, one that has benefited the two councils he has served, his constituents, local fishing fleet, entrepreneurs, small businesses, Downpatrick retailers, hoteliers, investors and many, many more. It is no surprise that he remains as keen for the local economy to work as he was in , said Mrs Donnelly.She added: ldquoThank your for all you do for NILGA and I have no doubt that hopefully for the next  years you will discover the secret to endless le. I always find you a pleasure to work with and a very helpful and hardworking councillor.Mr Hannaway described Cllr Curran as the ldquosage officers and councillors alike got to talk to and said the civic reception was a fitting occasion to mark his service to local politics, the district and his achievements.He continued: ldquoNot only has Dermot devoted his le to serving the people of our area, he has also been active as an executive member of NILGA since its inception and is currently its president, having previously served as chairman.ldquoAmong his many other responsibilities, Dermot has held positions in the Safety Partnership, the South Eastern Health Local Commissioning Group, Down Rural Area Partnership, Peace IV Partnership, Partnership Panel for NI, ARC, National Association of Councillors, FLAG Fisheries Fund and the Investment for Growth and Jobs Programme. He has also been a member of the Eastern Group Environmental Health since it was established and was its chairman in  and .ldquoAt the same time, Dermot has focused his attention on improving the infrastructure and economic possibilities within the district. He led the Tri-Fisheries Partnership and, as part of this, was instrumental in securing funding for a major environmental improvement scheme in Downpatrick and has campaigned for a much needed hotel in the town.Mr Hannaway added: ldquoWe often do not take the time to recognise the important work that the council and councillors do, year in and year out, but I am pleased that we have been able to do so this evening..prettyPhoto

title: Saints sunk at Bangor
story: THE Saints enjoyed their trip to the seaside to face Bangor FC in the Intermediate Cup on Saturday, and raced into an early two-goal lead.First, James Sofley and Oliver Duff exchanged passes before the latter drilled a low shot into the bottom corner from the edge of the area.The same two players were involved in the build up for the second, combining before James Milligan crossed for Justin Rea to head in at the back post.This bright opening by the visitors stung Bangor into action and they were soon on level terms, with two smart goals making it - at the break.Bangor set a high tempo early in the second half, pinning the Saints back and adding three goals to race into an unassailable lead.For the away side, James Sofley struck the post, and then had another attempt blocked which rebounded to Ethan Barr, who drilled it across the lsquokeeper and into the bottom corner to make it -.However, any hopes of a Saints comeback were well and truly extinguished by Michael Halliday adding a sixth for Bangor to seal their convincing victory.Bangor FC Saintfield United INTERMEDIATE CUP RD ROUND.prettyPhoto

title: SDLP selects Slieve Croob candidates for election
story: THE SDLP has selected its two Slieve Croob candidates to contest this Mayrsquos local government election.Sitting councillor Mark Murnin will be running for the party alongside SDLP stalwart Hugh Gallagher, who is chairman of the Castlewellan and Kilcoo branch.The selection of the two candidates was confirmed at a recent meeting in Downpatrick with Cllr Murnin and Mr Gallagher described as ldquovibrant and charismatic figures within the party and their local communities.Cllr Murnin mdash the current Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairman mdash said that over the past years he had learnt the importance of work for his constituents and within his community.ldquoThose who voted me into council in the first place will always remain my top priority, he continued. ldquoIt is a tremendous honour to serve and work for them and carry out the mandate entrusted to me by my party.ldquoI am delighted that Hugh Gallagher has put his name forward to run in Slieve Croob and I have no doubt that together we will be able to achieve great things for the people of the area.Mr Gallagher, who is contesting his first election, said he has been working on the ground with locals for many years and believed the time was right for him to represent the people at council level.ldquoAs someone who has worked in the mental health sector for many years, I am aware of the pressures people of all ages are facing, he continued.ldquoWe need to get the suicide rate down to zero and protect our local community services. If the Assembly is not up and running, councillors need to further lead by example as my colleagues within the SDLP already do.South Down MLA Colin McGrath, who spoke at the selection meeting, said some of the other local parties seemed to be reluctant to announce their election candidates.ldquoThat is not the case with the SDLP, he continued. ldquoOur history is of the utmost integrity and transparency. I am incredibly proud of Mark and Hugh and what they have achieved both to date and after the election. I look forward to the energetic campaign ahead, he added..prettyPhoto

title: outstanding quality at second calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. title: ruas winter fair to become important dairy showcase
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. title: celebrations as veterans lodge officially opens at new premises
story: Dignitaries including MP Alun Cairns, Penarth Town Council mayor Jon Luxton and Barry Town Council mayor Leighton Roland were amongst others who attended the ceremony at the Amelia Farm Trust in Barry.Woodyrsquos Lodge was set up by Penarth woman Sian Woodland in memory of her fianceacute Paul Woodland, who died on a military training exercise in October .It was set up in February  and aims to provide veterans with access to charities, advice, counselling and a place to socialise.The charity moved from HMS Cambria to Amelia Trust Farm, just off of Five Mile Lane on the edge of Barry.Dr David Trotman, the CEO for Woodyrsquos Lodge, said: ldquoThe facilities in Amelia Farm Trust are amazing. We are looking activities where we can get people on the farm working with the animals.ldquoWoodyrsquos Lodge has grown and grown since its beginning and it will continue to grow.Sian Woodland, who is the communications director at the lodge, said: ldquoThe partnership between Woodyrsquos Lodge and the Farm is fantastic. Itrsquos taken us a long time to get everything up and running and we are blown away by everyone who came to our official opening.Woodyrsquos Lodge is open to all types of veterans.Mike Hughes, , is a former police officer who attends the lodge. He says the lodge is a way for him to share memories and also help others.He said: ldquoYou walk in Woodyrsquos and you donrsquot have to tell anyone everything, no one makes assumptions or judges you.ldquoItrsquos a lovely place to come to be able to talk to people and I know you can talk to everyone and anyone but therersquos certain things you canrsquot say. If other veterans want to share things that have happened for them, Irsquom there to listen.ldquoThere is nothing bad that can be said and everyone can just sit down, have a coffee and chat.Visit woodyslodge.org article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment        -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: barry youngster enjoys party fit for a princess
story: A party fit for a princess" "   typemchtype" ""Nine-year-old enjoys party fit for a princessParty guests and games" "   typemchtype" Nine-year-old enjoys party fit for a princessA Disney s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentNINE-YEAR-OLD Blisse Mellens enjoyed an ultimate Princess birthday party when the Rays of Sunshine childrenrsquos charity granted her birthday wish.The Barry youngster, who attends Ysgol y Deri, in Penarth, lives with Periventricular Nodular Hetertopia and Polymicrogyria, a condition that causes abnormal development of the brain.She lives with epilepsy, uses a wheelchair, and also suffers from movement disorders that restrict her from walking, talking, and eating.Despite her condition, Blisse has a very active imagination and loves bright colours, lights, and listening to music, especially Disney music.As she is non-verbal and has a developmental delay, Blisse is a sensory seeker who loves to see and listen to big Disney performances.To make her wish of having a big Disney Princess party become a reality, Rays of Sunshine Wish ambassador, Sophie Washington, worked closely with Blissersquos family to organise a day full of bright Disney Princess fun.Blissersquos family and friends were joined by princesses, Rapunzel, Belle, Ariel and Elsa.There was also face painting, balloon modelling, multisensory music performances, and a special soft play area, where Blisse was able to play with the princesses out of her wheelchair.Blissersquos mum, Laura said: ldquoEach birthday is milestone for Blisse and even though she was struggling with her seizures that day and wasnt feeling too well, Im so grateful to have lovely pictures of her and all her friends.ldquoThe entertainment was amazing, and all the children enjoyed it.ldquoThank you to Rays of Sunshine for allowing us to have a fabulous birthday that we will always treasure.Sophie Washington, Rays of Sunshine wish ambassador, added: "It was an absolute pleasure to help organise Blisses wish.ldquoId like to say a massive thank you to Fantasia and Melody Meadows, also known as Belle and Rapunzel, and photographer Charlie Dearman for giving up their time to make Blisses wish come true.ldquoI couldnt have done it without you all.Thanks also to Mandy at the Barry Masonic Hall, Dave at KeyCreate, Alana and Linda at Brushes and Balloons, and Helen at Soft Tots Soft Play for helping to make Blisses party truly special. Rays of Sunshine is an incredible charity, and Im honoured to be a part of it."For information about Rays of Sunshine Childrens Charity and its work or to apply for a wish to be granted, visit www.raysofsunshine.org.uk article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment        -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: dozens of drivers dodge ban as result of loophole
story: Analysis of DVLA data reveals  drivers in the Vale of Glamorgan area have dodged a ban after being given  or more penalty points on their licence ndash the usual threshold for losing a licence.Road safety charity Brake has slammed the current system, which it says is allowing ldquorepeat offenders to exploit loopholes in the law.Joshua Harris, director of campaigns at Brake, said it is ldquohugely concerning that so many offenders are being allowed to keep driving.He said continued: ldquoBy ignoring the exploitation of the lsquoexceptional hardshiprsquo loophole that allows unsafe drivers to remain on our roads, the Government and courts are complicit in increasing the risk to the public. The charity is calling for the loophole to be closed as part of its Roads to Justice campaign, which says an urgent review should be carried out.Currently,a driver can convince a magistrate that they, or an innocent party, will face lsquoexceptional hardshiprsquo as a result of losing their licence they may be permitted to keep it.The latest figures show there are almost , drivers across Great Britain who have retained their licences despite passing the points limit, some with more than  or  points.In the Vale of Glamorgan the highest number of points received by one driver who is still allowed to drive is .John Bache, chairman of the Magistrates Association, said added: ldquoThe process for establishing exceptional hardship is robust ndash magistrates scrutinise every case very carefully.A Ministry of Justice spokesman said: ldquoThe vast majority of drivers who get  penalty points are automatically disqualied. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment        -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
